description: They may not have the best dim sum in the city but service is excellent. It's always fast and attentive. Food are great.
author: J L.

description:
Ate dinner here last night. Steamed chicken and Walnut prawns come out....... Then NOTHING. We basically finished it and had to ask when our other food was coming. Took a very long time and by that time we weren't really hungry anymore and were frustrated.

I've been here for dim sum before and it was ok but dinner was a disaster. Only came here for dinner because the wait at Yan Yan was 1.5 hours which in hind sight would have been a much better choice.
author: William S.

description:
S&T Hong Kong Seafood for Dimsum during lunch time is not worth it at all. All the dumplings and noodle taste very bland and a lot of the items tasted a little extra steamy like it was microwaved. The prices for eat dish was quite pricey, just heads up.

The waiter that helped us constantly went outside for a smoke break, and I never seen him wash his hands when he comes back...

The location here is quite small, apparently it gets busy on the weekend since this is one of the only Dimsum spots in Sunset area; definitely would drive extra 20 minutes to SF Chinatown for Dimsum next time. 

I wouldn't come back to this location, sorries. Hopefully their dinner is a lot better than their lunch menu.
author: Joey C.

description:
Came here at 1pm on a Sunday and the two of us were seated right away. Despite seeing reviews with vermin in food (which is usually an automatic no for me) we decided to give it a try.

Food: every dish lacked one ingredient - flavor.
- siu mai: no flavor, small & sad
- baked BBQ Pork bun: filling was good, bun was bad. Very small 
- pan fried turnip cake: this was fine 
- shrimp stuffed eggplant: no sauce to help the flavor along. Tasted only like oil. Eggplant was slightly undercooked.
- deep fried shrimp ball: smaller than standard but was well fried. Couldn't really taste the flavor of the shrimp paste and was pretty bland because of that. Doused it in sweet and sour to help it go down
- Shanghai dumplings (Xiao long Bao): skin fell apart 2/4 of them because it was stuck to bottom of the tin. No soup and lacked flavor.
- shrimp noodle roll: standard, which was better than everything else we had
- har gow: also standard which is A+ for here

Service: I don't really consider service at dim sum places. Only here for the food. Water is $1 (legal?) and tea is $1.25 (not uncommon). Have to ask for soy sauce & chili sauce.

I have dim sum every week in the bay area and this fell below even average expectations.
author: Dani T.

description:
Came here for Dim Sum on a Sunday. Above average standard dim sum fare for a reasonable price. I can't speak for the regular menu - but this is place is a good four star dim sum joint.

For the dim sum - you make your order on a piece of paper. I didn't see carts moving around but all the standard delicious standards are here.

Would definitely come back again.
author: Doug R.

description:
A decent dim sum and chinese food spot, but the prices here are insane! Coming from southern california/the 626 area, I can't imagine some of the prices I saw at this spot. 

The food is alright, but for this price, there are probably a half dozen spots on the same street where you can grab a similar meal!

The service here also didn't leave the best impression on me. Slow and rude, and if you're going to have a stereotypical asian restaurant, you should at least have corresponding prices on your food!
author: Andrew T.

description:
If there is 0 star, would definitely leave a zero for this place.
The waiting time for getting seats was not too bad, but once you ordered, it took long time for the food to come. We ordered 1 extra and waited for 25 minutes still not come, then decided to go so ask for canceling this one, the manager refused and added it to the bill, and forced us to pay because she said the food is coming and we need to take it. However, they took away our plates and cleaned up the table, we explained that we don't have time to stay but the manager brought new plates and asked us to wait for the food to come, totally ridiculous and she was giving attitudes and no apologies for the late of delivering food.
Super rude host and the food is just okay (if not bad), definitely not worth to come here.
author: Taier G.

description:
Awful service, terrible owner who have a resting "B" face and screams at her staffs! 

Our was reservation at 5:30 and my sister was running late at 5:45. The owner comes screamed at us, we need to start your food, I need this table back @ 7:00?!? Why is that our problem?!? You should not have booked your reservation so close. To make the experience worst the waiter handed us the bill, we questioned if the tip was included he goes no but I'll add 18% for you.How is that illegal for CRAP food and service. 

Bottom line: food is mediocre, dirty establishment and service is awful = will not be returning!
author: Tina T.

description:
One of the better Chinese Restaurants in the area with friendly staff (the owner can be loud but she's actually very friendly with everyone).  Their food is pretty yummy here and you get a  healthy portion of delicious food. The staff and kitchen can be real accommodating for dietary restrictions and everything comes out piping hot.  

You will pay a premium for seafood but you get good quality. We paid $38.00 a pound for Geoduck (was 4 pounds) and it two ways; sashimi style on the tail and salt and pepper with tofu for the head. Was made perfectly and the portion appeared close to 4 pounds. I always go for their soup of their day which varies but it's very good. In fact, I jokingly asked the waiter if we can have a refill. He came out with another pot! To be honest, I haven't had anything here I didn't like or that did not taste right or too greasy. My only complain is this place is very busy and the cleanness could be better.. way better.
author: Eric T.

description: 3.5 stars. Neighborhood dim sum in the Sunset District. The service is surprisingly decent because I think the owner is very hands-on. Food is also decent too. My family loved the meal!
author: L S.

description:
Ahhh.  San Francisco.  Late August, typical grey sky (Indian Summer had not yet arrived), a fresh chill in the air.  After circling the block several times, we got lucky and managed to wedge our car into a parking spot with a tinge of "pink" on one end.  And all for a late Saturday night nibble in a slightly seedy, little Cantonese restaurant in the outer Sunset that our Taiwanese AirBnb host had recommended.  

We had a brief pause to scrutinize the menu while sitting in the only two seats in a waiting area that accommodates 4.5 people, before they escorted us to our table.  They were busy, loud, and I was one of only two non-Asians in the lot.  That was a good sign.

Another "ahhh".  This was my reaction as I slowly sipped my intensely fragrant jasmine tea.  I started dusting off cobwebbed memories of "SF past" , the smells, the tastes, the feelings that had been lovingly stored away, ready and waiting to emerge when I finally returned to The City.  I'd been gone way too long and I had only 4 days to make up for lost time.

War won ton soup on a crisp night was a given.  The delicate broth with delicious meat filled dumplings, sharing the bowl with shrimp, scallops, squid, bbq pork, chicken, and bok choy was so satisfying.  We were good. We slurped in peace.

We added a pork and oyster pot dish that also featured tofu, shitaki mushrooms, whole garlic, and ginger.  Lets not forget the one bowl of white rice we shared, as we unsuccessfully tried to avoid white starch.   Just can't do that in a real Chinese restaurant.  

My frugal nature always dictates that leftovers not be left behind.  And while we had plenty, that's ok, we had a little refrigerator in our Airbnb room.  

Dammit, do these leftovers mean I now have one less opportunity to knock off a bookmark in SF?  Nah...not gonna happen.
author: Wendy B.

description: This place used to be so solid. Food is still pretty good, but they used to be excellent. Dim sum is good. Place is getting really old and runned down. Really in need of a remodel or at least a thorough cleaning and overhaul.
author: Ming W.

description:
I always come to S&T because it is near my house, and it is one of the more upscale chinese restaurants in the area. It isn't the cheapest place by any stretch of the imagination, but it's a good option for family style dinner's or dim sum lunch. 

The service is the most subjective part of this restaurant as it appears from reading other reviews. I personally have not had any major service issues with the waiters and waitresses here. They are all quick on their feet and are almost always occupied; no one being complacent, standing around doing nothing!

As for the food, most options are pretty good, and the portion sizes are fair. It is a seafood restaurant after all, so definitely try out their selection of seafoods.

I took a star off for the long wait times during rush hours, and the noise levels. It's sometimes hard to hear someone from across the table here, so you feel left out in conversations :(
author: Golden H.

description:
I guess I would consider my grandparents high rollers of ST Hong Kong Sea Food. Our family has been going here since the 90's. The waiters always take good care of us and are very attentive. They give us new plates when its piled with crab shells, refill the tea pot when it's empty, and sometimes even give us free dessert. 

Food is consistent, never had any major problems when we come here. Always looking forward to lunch or dinner here with my family.
author: Nicole Y.

description: Good basic Chinese food in outer Sunset district of San Francisco.  The restaurant prepares the basics well- Mayonnaise Shrimp with Walnuts, Ma Po Tofu and Beef with Radish Soup.  The deep fried Flounder with. Soy based sauce was good.  I especially like the Abalone Mushroom with Broccoli in Oyster Sauce.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
This place has rats and roaches. The tables in the back of the restaurant are especially dirty and the carpets are stained from years of... something. Would not return until they clean up.

Owner lady can be somewhat of a b*tch with her attitude. The waiters are great and nice though.

Food is pretty good.
author: Gordon Y.

description:
I've been here a couple times and, for the price, this place can satisfy your cheap dim-sum cravings.

I like the sticky rice in a leaf, soup dumplings, siu mai, fried rice, and a couple more items but I can never remember exactly what I get as I just keep ordering and ordering. The calamari here is only $2 and it is pretty good!

The soup dumplings are not the soup dumplings you think.. They are actually dumplings in soup. I believe the Shanghai dumplings are the pork soup dumplings that many come here looking for! I only mention this because I came here and ordered the wrong item 3 times before getting the item I intended. 

The service is alright. They get confused by what you're saying kind of easily, so make sure you're explicit with that you need and you'll be fine!
P.S.: Big thank you to the servers who recognized me during my last visit and gave me a complimentary dessert! You rock!
author: Alexi G.

description:
Price is expensive for what you get.  The restaurant itself looks fairly clean but looks can be deceiving.  During our meal, we happened to see a small mouse running around on the floor under the table next to us!!!  Felt pretty disgusted afterwards.

We told the staff and they just shrugged it off as if it was nothing.  Sigh.....
author: Alejandro M.

description:
Thanks to a hook-up, our annual friends-giving dinner was hosted here, with one unique aspect - they prepared a king crab that we had imported in from Norway. It was pretty fantastic - we got to see the crab, live, before it was whisked into the kitchen to be prepared several different, delicious ways.

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Decent parking available on Noriega and up side residential streets
+ Fast, efficient service, with almost too many dishes coming out at once
+ Each crabby dish was incredible, from the salted egg fried crab, to the noodle-y dish, to the custard baked in the crab's head
+ Extremely reasonable pricing for all the food our table consumed

This was a filling and delicious evening, for sure.
author: Claire S.

description:
The food here is very good. Not quite excellent but definitely what we had was flavorful and worth having again. But there are a couple of minor issues and one major issue that could keep me from returning. 

We were there for a family dinner, Six adults, two toddlers and an infant. We had reserved a table and it was ready when we arrived on-time at 5:30pm on a Saturday night. I found it somewhat annoying that the server tried to dictate where the children should sit before they arrived. It was quite obvious that he was trying to maintain a traffic lane in a restaurant that they had overbooked with large tables. While this is not uncommon in Chinese restaurants, especially around Lunar New Year, the Fire Inspector might find issue with this. 

The woman manager/owner? had a very bad habit of yelling across the restaurant at her staff as well as customers. Perhaps she has hearing issues? Either way, this is inappropriate and quite annoying in a crowded restaurant. 

The worse is the condition of the Men's Room. We were there early in the evening and it smelled horrible. There was water on the ground, paper products on the floor. It needed a thorough steam cleaning and bleach disinfecting. I hope that the kitchen is a 1000% cleaner.
author: Dexter D.

description: I would give a ZERO star if possible. Worst experience everrrrr! Today is freaking Mothers Day, where all ppl should be happy and cheerful about! But the owner is so freaking rude and have people wait for freaking 1 hour straight without any food, despite the fact that you were already seated! The machines were broken, and the staffs just told people to wait wait wait without any compensations. Staffs forgot peoples order and have the customers waited without any apologies. Never come here if you want to have a good time. All frustration and drama!
author: Ryan J.

description:
So far I think S&T has been my favorite dim sum in SF. Dim sum is pretty hard to differentiate, it's all steamed or fried at the end of the day so the difference with each restaurant is basically quality of ingredients and execution. While other places I've tried in SF are overpriced, S&T is more fairly priced while still offering the same variety of dim sum options and slightly higher quality than what I've tasted around the city.

Here, you order from a piece of paper, and waiters check on the list and bring items to your table. I think they also have carts around but I also like this paper method to see exactly what the restaurant has and so that you can easily order your favorite items. I tried the Chinese broccoli, xiao long bao, har cheung/shrimp noodles, ribs, shu mai. taro pastry, egg tarts, and all were tasty.

It does get really busy on the weekends, so come before 10:30 if you don't want to wait. Other than that it's pretty easy to order, has most of the options to satisfy a small or large group at dim sum, and is likely to become my go-to dim sum in SF!
author: Steven V.

description: Adapted to local Hongkong-nese taste, EVERY dish is scrumptious. The chef is simply the best chef, not forgetting the excellent service!  Highly recommend pork feet, chicken, steamed/stir friend fresh grouper, spot prawns, and pork neck. Been frequenting for years--quality is very consistent.
author: Paulette T.

description: My family and I were looking for somewhere to eat around the neighbor. We were having late dinner since we just came back from a Labor Day weekend short trip. We felt bad asking if the places are still open for business at 830. Most of the places were not welcoming except for S&T! We didn't take our sweet time and we went ahead to order the entrees. We had seafood fried rice, BBQ pork, sizzling beef and chicken chow menu. The food was really juicy, tender and just flavorful. In addition the service was really friendly.
author: Kay D.

description: Serviceable. I came here for lunch on a weekday afternoon. No wait since it was in the middle of a weekday. Their dim sum was okay. If you don't know much about dim sum, this place will be great for you. However, if you're Chinese and frequent dim sum restaurants a lot, this place is average. I've had better, but this place isn't bad. They made the fook kin fried rice pretty good, though.
author: Edmond T.

description: Great hot and sour soup and a huge variety of food. Wait can be long and the service is just "ok" but it's always packed so that says something. Very authentic and the seafood options are fresh and tasty.
author: Laurel M.

description:
Solid dim sum - gets busy by 11am, so if you don't want to wait on weekends, arrive by 10:30! I've been here with family a few times previously, and I think I had remembered the food being a bit better than it was... but on my latest visit I tried quite a few items:

Shrimp dumplings - good standby, wrappers seemed a little overcooked
Shiu mai - a bit more seasoning could be good
Shrimp and chive dumplings - I really liked how they executed these! Lots of filling and good pan-fried wrapper texture.
Bean curd roll with pork - Texturally really nice but also a bit underseasoned
Calamari - A little greasy and underseasoned as well, but fairly cheap at under $3
Chicken feet - Tasty! Just wish the portion were a bit bigger for the price.
Salted egg yolk lava buns - Had to get these since they're the specialty! Hot and sweet.
Sesame dumplings with peanut flour - Lacked uniformity as you can see from the photo, but the filling was sweet and the mochi was good.

Overall, more flavor would really improve the dishes. Their menu is very extensive, though, so it may just be a matter of trying different items - which I will definitely do the next time I come by.
author: Delia Z.

description: I had read the comments about the health issues but decided to give HK Seafood a try anyway. Well, turns out they were very true. Ordered some bok choy dish and each head was full of sand D: The other dish I got also wasn't as good. Bummed because I really wanted to like it as the workers are nice but unfortunately impossible...
author: Hello E.

description: There was a cockroach in the chicken feet. Glad that I wasn't that hungry and eat it immediately. So gross..
author: Justin Z.

description:
Before going on a Pokemon adventure, my friends and I had to fuel up. My friend suggested this place because it was his go-to dim sum place. 

There are no carts or ladies yelling dim sum names. We filled out a sheet of paper and orders came out whenever it was ready. I guess this is more efficient, but sucks for people that don't know their dim sum well. 

The one dish that I judge at dim sum places is the shrimp rice noodle because it is my favorite dish and so many places can't make it right. Not this place though! The noodles were soft and thin enough that when you try to grab it with chopsticks, it will break (unless you are super skilled with chopsticks). Not the silkiest noodle though but I still enjoyed it a lot. :) 

Service was surprisingly good. They cleared the table quickly whenever they saw an empty dish. I don't expect much service from Chinese restaurants because I don't go to them for that, so this place certainly exceed my expectations. :)
author: Michelle L.

description: One of the waiters was extremely rude. In the dim sum paper, it said water is $1 and that tea is $1.25 per person. We only requested for hot water and they charged us $1.25 per person. It is not a huge amount of money. The attitude of the worker was unacceptable. He said to go talk to the owner who isn't here, so I said that I shouldn't pay them since they can't resolve our issues. He just walked away and I had to request a different waiter to get the bill so I could pay. I'm not sure he knows what business he is in. This is a service business and people have many places they can go to eat. If you can't treat customers nicely, you should get out of the service business.
author: Janice L.

description:
I went to S&T for the first time today and I felt like I went in a time machine to my youth.  Growing up Chinese and needing to be careful with money we were in places like this all the time.  If you are repulsed by spotty service, sketchy bathrooms, Dragon Lady owners, and all Chinese clientele, then don't bother.  To me, that's all part of the je nais sais quoi.  Those are all the things you ignore because you want a place that spends its energy on making excellent food.  

Here's an example:  the roast duck.  A duck is not like a giant Costco chicken where you can pull off giant hunks of boneless meat.  A duck has a lot of bones in it.  You can pay $20 for the Peking Duck and avoid acknowledging that, but when you get the $6 dim sum plate, you're getting about seven pieces of duck and three of them are more bone than not.  But I put those pieces in my mouth and I remember... notice that this crispy skin is righteous!  Notice that the amount of salt is just perfect.  Note that the fat is cooked enough that you just want to suck on it.  Dealing with the bones makes you have your moment of Zen... you can't just shove it down and fail to appreciate these nuances.  Then you go back to the meaty pieces and really enjoy it. 

Or let's try the Chinese broccoli.  Sure it's a huge plate because vegetables are relatively cheap.  But it's cooked perfectly... all the bitterness is gone, but the crunch is just right, and the oyster sauce complements the actual taste of the vegetable perfectly.   They are artists back in that kitchen.  

Dumplings are good, but actual bite sized.  I admit I've gotten used to places where they make the huge ones, but dumplings are meant to be a one-bite experience.  Have it that way. 

I actually can't wait to come back.  I wish I could take my dad.  He would call it soul food.
author: G M.

description:
My mom wanted to come here for dim sum on Memorial Day.  Yeah yeah yeah, it's gunna be a long wait time, it's a holiday, it's going to be busy.. whatever.  We still went out as a family of 5 to eat lunch.  

This isn't the usual place we go to get dim sum but we decided to try someplace new.  So we get a number, wait a little long to get seated but we were OK, we get seated, take our order on the paper (where you mark the quantity of dishes you want), then waited. And waited..... about 20 min pass and we ask 2 waiters to check on our order.  Nothing happens... Literally, the waiters didn't even come back to our table to inform us of what happened when they "checked" on our order.  Wait another 10 minutes and my mom physically gets up to go to the front desk area and ask the lady owner (definitely the owner bcus we saw 4 framed photos on the wall with lady owner IN the photos).  Once my mom asks, lady owner is INSTANTLY annoyed and starts barking in Cantonese (and I can understand everything) to all her employees and realize that our order was never even put into the ordering system. 

My fam and I were patiently waiting, seriously, so patient that we had the time to check out the interior of the restaurant to look at the owner's framed photos on the walls..

So finally she says, "1 minute, your food will come out" and she starts off with dessert.  The almond jell-o dessert thing we ordered.  Which was fine.. but really... as our first dish... Alright lady.  We ate it anyways of course to pass the time..

Then it gets worse, we wait again for a more.... hot dish... then a waitress takes out noodles (like an egg noodle chow mein dish), then sets it onto the table... my brother uses his chop stick to instantly dive into the noodle dish to put some on his plate.  Then ALL OF A SUDDEN the waitress says "Opps wrong table" and takes the dish back while my bro is MID-GRABBIN in the noodle dish already.  Literally noodles fall off of the dish and onto the table and the waitress picks it up with her hands and says "It's ok, it's ok" and puts it back onto the dish and walks back into the kitchen direction.  I was literally so disgusted.  I already know FOR SURE she was going to bring that dish back into the kitchen and serve it out again onto the correct table.  Fucking gross.

So my family and I are almost traumatized (maybe a little exaggerated term, but you get what I mean) at this point after everything that has already happened and then when another server was taking out some steamed dim sum to another table, the lady owner grabs the dishes from the tray while the waitress is holding it, checks all of the steam containers and whichever one we ordered she just threw them onto our table and says (in Cantonese) "just serve this table first, they're whining and complaining." EXCUSE ME LADY OWNER????!?!??!? Omg at this point I really wanted to say something but tbh she prob wouldn't have understood me anyways with my broken ass Chinglish accent. 

All the waiters and waitresses literally all seemed so stressed and tired out...  Probably cus it was busy but probably more because they have a barking boss lady that makes them all stressed out! Trust me, I was a waitress before, bosses need to chill and be coo if they want to run a good-serviced restaurant.

But anyways, woah lady owner you need to fucking chill.  Your food is coo but your attitude makes your restaurant disgusting.  How dare you go around to your CUSTOMERS and tell us that we're whining and complaining RIGHT in front of our faces, when you literally are the one whining and complaining to all your startled employees.. Super disgusting and rude. I give some serious props to your employees who work for you.
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
I love coming here for dim sum because I never have to wait in line!
Dim sum here is good AND it's inexpensive compared to Koi Palace or Dragon Beaux. Though they don't have any fancy squid ink dumplings or truffle buns, they have the classics, and that's all I need to leave full and happy. 
Each small dish ranges from about $3-$6 and come with pretty generous portions too. I usually come with one other person and our bill is always under $35 which is a STEAL for how much food we got. We had a lot of leftovers to bring home too. 
If your usual dim sum spot is too busy, check this place out!
author: Christine L.

description: Average Chinese restaurant that serves dim sum in the Outer Sunset, you don't see many restaurants serving dim sum in the Avenues these days. From the best of my knowledge this was the old Tai Wu before the King Drive location. The furniture and decor is a little bit dated and there are a lot of pictures of the owner lady and famous people around the restaurant which makes it look a little tacky. The dim sum here is decent, you order off a paper menu and everything is made to order. We ordered the Spare Ribs, Siu Mai, Har Gow, Pork Blood, Beef Balls and Beef Chow Fun. The Spare Ribs had a weird taste, but the Siu Mai, Har Gow, Pork Blood and Beef Balls were on point. The service here was good, the waitstaff were very polite and did not rush us despite coming towards closing time. I speak Chinese, but I did overhear the waitstaff speaking good English with some of the customers. I had a good conversation with the staff during my meal and they seem to be very friendly and customer service oriented. But a thing they can improve on is their sanitation in terms of the bathroom and cleaning the carpet. Overall gets the job done for dim sum in the Avenues.
author: Peter C.

description:
I've been here for dim sum and dinner many times.  I am pleased with both meals.  Dim sum is good and fresh.  Best is that it's consistent time after time. My favourite dim sum here is the boiled tripe. It's very tender and easy to bite!  The shrimp dumplings, Siu mai, shrimp rice rolls usually come out piping hot.  Service here is also quite good. There are a lot of waiters on guard so it's easily to wave someone down.

Dinner is also very good. No matter what you order, there is a certain level of quality to it. Even when we ordered their house soup, it was delicious!

This is not your local cheap Chinese joint. This is pricier than most of the Chinese restaurants in the sunset. I think of them as the Koi Palace of the sunset. Not as pretentious but offering a similar level and quality of Chinese dishes.  I really recommend this place. Their food is excellent!
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Open on Labor Day. 

The dim sum was good. Pretty standard to what you will find in the Bay Area. Lowest priced dish is $3 and ranges to $11 noodle dishes. 

The sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf was my favorite dish. $5 for 2. 

The service is curt and just trying to run the business. Hence... All waiters are on the struggle bus. Running around to place dishes, bus tables, refill waters all while trying to take more orders. 

Overall: pretty clean. Service wasn't horrible. But probably will not return.
author: Stephen C.

description:
My extended family likes to come to this restaurant since the 10 course banquet meal is cheap and the food is good. I thought the food wasn't bad. It's your typical Hong Kong style food with the cold appetizers, steamed fish, fried rice, shrimp and walnut prawns, etc. The pumpkin and salted egg coated crab was the unique dish from the offerings. Food was saltier to me. Service was fine as the waiters were attentive to our party of five tables.

Separate men and women bathroom. They are smelly and have wet floors.
author: Jackie S.

description: Good food and pretty quick service! But dirty carpet and bathroom need a makeover for sure . It's become unattractive to customer. Recommend to anyone who doesn't care about anything else but good food.
author: Eindra S.

description:
Dim sum was good today. Better than I recall from the past. A bit salty as I felt fairly thirsty hours later. The waiters were nice and I saw the owner working hard taking care of the bills.
The 5 of us ordered doubles of 6 dishes and all tasted pretty good. I liked the bamboo wrapped sticky rice the best. It was moist and full of stuffing.  Siu mai and har gow were good. The special pan fried chow menu had too much gravy but tasted good with lots of shrimp and squid mixed with mushroom, bok choy and pork.  The fried taro balls were good too. Egg tarts were tiny and just Ok.
I would consider another trip to try other things but will have to load up on water to flush all the salt or msg out.
author: Ry T.

description:
I could care less how many famous people have eaten at S&T.  I would never return again after eating there for dinner.  This place is too dirty and too expensive for the type of food, service and ambiance you get.  

If you are a new customer, they sit you in the main dining room, where the decor is nicer and the service is a little better.  Unfortunately, my grandparents have eaten there several times so we were considered the "regulars."  We were seated in the other room which was incredibly old, dirty and completely unappealing.  Keep in mind, you get charged the same whether you sit in the nice room or the not-so-nice room.  All the chairs in the other room were so gross - upholstery stained/soiled, ripped and disgusting.  They have no shame as some of the chair backs have duck tape wrapped around them.  

We ordered 8 dishes, which was more than enough for our table of 7.  Every dish that evening was incredibly greasy and laced with MSG.  It literally gave me a stomachache.  The portions are huge but not worth what you pay.  Quality is just fair and none of the ingredients were that special.  Service was lacking and I was unimpressed by the owner's presence.  She is the lady with the short spiky hair in all the photos on the wall.  Overall, poor experience and regret having dined there (although wasn't my choice).  The total tab was $138.  I could have spent my money at a different Chinese seafood restaurant and gotten a much better meal and experience.
author: Liv A.

description:
Dim Sum on a weekday. Service was a bit surprising; there were some odd things, such as chili sauce and soy sauce seem to be in short supply - needed to request the small amount again and again. On the other hand, immediate attention to an additional chair to hold my brief case & my guests purse was appreciated not requested and UNEXPECTED. Service was a mishmash of tremendously great , and terribly bad. Since I like mishmash, it was fine. Hilarious encounter w/ a recent immigrant posing as a service person was the stuff of SNL, gotta just laugh and move on!

The owners picture w/ Mr. Ed (da mayor) on the wall, establishing "credibility". Thought the food (Dim Sum) was A-OK. not great, a couple of dishes a bit aged (cooked in a prior dynasty). 

Ordered a variety of Dim Sum dishes using the archetypal order sheet and pencil. Bill was $52.00 for 3 of us, w/ the rounding tip of $8.00 it was a $60.00 ante for an a-ok Dim Sum lunch for 3 w/ a few pieces left to take home. Nota cheap joint, but overall it was A-OK. 

Probably will be back if the Dim Sum mood strikes on Noriega, OR to sample their Cantonese fare; although their capitalistic restaurateur bent has caused Singapore, Malaysian, Thai style noodle dishes to appear on their menu. Its EssF so gotta love that international flare of fare.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
We were kind of late for dim sum, but still few tables here. Looks like full of locals. I was hoping of dim dim carts, but not many places have carts nowadays. 

We checked off some regular dim sums from the dim sum card, 3 of us, we ordered 8 items .. still have a bit left overs.

Chinese Chives with Pork Blood - I am not a fan or pork blood, but hubby and mother-in-law likes it.

Steamed Rice Noodle with Chicken and Bitter-melon - I like the rice noodle, silky, smooth and chewy.

Next was our typical items:
Steamed Bean Curb with Meat, Steamed Malay Cake, Chicken Feet in Abalone Sauce, 
Deep Fried Shrimp Ball, Fried Calamari.

Only item I was very disappointed was the Chicken Feet in Abalone Sauce, chicken feet was hard! I think I will stick with my regular steamed chicken feet next time.

Finally, my must get every time I can to any dim sum place (I should really learn how to make this): Runny Salted Egg Yolk Bun.

This place did a very good job. I love it so much!!!

I would come back for this bun!
author: Sandi C.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Sunday around noon. The wait at that time for a party of 3 was about 10-15 minutes, not bad. 

Here is probably my main reason for writing this review; we were seated and a waiter brought us tea (tea is $1.25 a person...water...tap water is $1 a person....absurd!!!). If you order tea, water is free.

The quality of dim sum is okay, probably won't come back (when I came to S&T in the past, it was always for dinner). Portuguese egg tarts are kind of a rip off, literally the regular egg tarts with some char on the top. Highlight of the meal, as always was their char sui, always a must get, day or night.
author: Ray K.

description:
What do you do when you want Cantonese food but don't want to brave the crowds or the dirty streets of Chinatown? You head out to the Sunset district and find a place along Noriega St.

The other reviews are true, the rice noodle dishes such as ha cheong (shrimp rice noodle) are done particularly well here. Lo bak go (turnip cake) had a nice crunch to it and definitely better than most I've ever had. Another staple 乾炒牛河 (Dry beef chow fun) although slightly under seasoned was at least not overly greasy.

No old ladies pushing carts around but my otherwise pleasant late lunch at 2:30pm was constantly being interrupted by the owner shouting detailed instructions in Cantonese to her staff on how to set the tables. Really? What's the big deal? I don't think the dinner rush is going to happen for at least 2 hours. And if you really need to tell your staff that when setting the table there should be a plate at each setting there is something seriously wrong. My mom suggested I should make a recording and play it back for the owner just so she can hear how silly it is for a customer to listen to this nonsense. Come to think of it, I may do that the next time I'm in town.
author: Glen L.

description:
Stopped by to have some dim sum since it was the closest place to where we were. Service was nice. The restaurant is not too big but they have large tables. Boyfriend and I had some usual good dishes: pork ribs, har gow, shrimp wrapped in rice sheets. Although we had some not so great dishes: the siu mai had a weird flavor of old meat probably from being frozen, the soup dumplings had no soup in them and the meat was all mushy along with the wrapper, egg custard tart's pastry was not baked long enough to make it crispy but the custard part was not bad. The dishes ranged in price from $3-$5. 

Overall, sadly we were not super happy with our dim sum experience here. We couldn't even finish two of the dishes.
author: Katherine L.

description: They don't know what a reservation means. Unbelievably stupid, owner starts yelling at staff
author: Wilson K.

description:
Food: Delicious and plenty of choice. 

Service: Good

Parking: Not too difficult to find parking around the restaurant

Space: Reasonable space between tables

One of the go to restaurant for family gathering.
author: Chin Man L.

description: Dim sum spot that is less crowded than most in the city. We got seated right away around 12pm, which was perfect for a table of 5. We ordered a lot of dishes along with the lobster noodles. The lobster had good flavor, but the noodles lacked - so don't forget to ask for their hot chili sauce to go with it. The chicken feet was also very flavorful. The Shanghai dumplings were dry inside and weren't great because it fell apart easily too. Since it was a friend's 2nd time having dim sum, they enjoyed it. Easier to talk to the waiters in Cantonese if you can, but they were super friendly to me. Pretty clean for a Chinese spot too.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This is the most authentic, Cantonese restaurant I know of in the city. Keep in mind that that includes the ambience, environment, noise-level, et cetera - you name it. 

Food: Good taste overall! I didn't get very thirsty after dinner. Yes, soy sauce chicken is one of their signature dishes, beef cubes are good, steamed fish used fresh fish (you can tell immediately from the texture), crab dishes were humongous, and beef brisket in soup in a clay pot was good.

Waiters and Boss/Owner Lady: Awesome! I love the environment! Warning: Don't come with high expectations if you can't handle the culture. Many of the regular customers are close with and know all of the waiters and Owner / Boss Lady. They are nice and just joke a lot. They have pictures with famous actors, singers, SF Mayor, etc.

We've been coming here for years!
Oh yeah, best to reserve a table.
author: Michael Y.

description:
This is the best tastes and good service Chinese restaurants in San Francisco area.
Only the seat not comfortable.
author: Lin Da N.

description:
the rating for their turnip cake compared to places in norcal and socal:

authentic / 5
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
NEGATIVE Score. Not worth the money. Service was horrible and while we were packing our left over food, the waiters and the boss took away all our utensil. We ask if they could wait and they totally ignored us so they can give the table to another party. Then my husband shouted out Hold On, we need to pack our food and the boss remark was, why don't you pack the food that's on the floor as well.

This business owner does not deserve your money. Stay Away!!!
author: Dee C.

description:
Great fried rice, bbq pork, soup! Sizzling beef was a family favorite (although not mine).

Would come back!
author: Heidi J.

description: Overall average Asian seafood restaurant in outer sunset, nothing too special. No line on a Thursday night for a party of ten people. Customer service are okay except the lady
author: Jasper K.

description:
Food: 3.7 out of 5
Service: I will give 4---today is a raining day, I am sitting next to the window. The sun just smiles at us for a second, and the waiter already walk to me and ask if I need the shade curtain down... very impressive...
author: Hao W.

description: I have been here 4 times, every time they over charged us. 3 people they charged us for 4 pepole, (3 times), we have to pay $1.25 more for the tea. 8 people they charged us as 10 people, we have to pay $2.5 more for the tea. They also charge ten cents for the plastic bag every time whether you ask for or not!
author: Joseph W.

description: Foods are great. I loved the mixed sea foods,salt & pepper porkchop, crispy fried tofu & mushrooms with oyster sauce. The waiter is so nice. He gave me free "soup of the day" to try. Everything was great! It was a good experience. And surely we will come back again
author: Bella A.

description:
Their Dim Sum is hot and fresh. But they really need to improve their customer service! The waitress that wears glasses is THE worst server I've ever seen and not to say the others are better than her!

Advice to the owner: train your employees on their customer service skills and you will guarantee to have more business!
author: Jaylene L.

description:
Stopped by here around 10:30 on a Sunday. It's has all your standard dim sum fanfare sans the rolling carts. I felt it to be a pretty solid experience by SF standards.

In my opinion, its as good as the places in Chinatown. Perhaps just a hair below Koi Palace. Definitely less crowded and without the monster wait..
author: James S.

description:
I came here for dinner for the first time today. The food here is delicious and the service is good.

Here are some of the items I had:
- Crab Meat Soup as a starter
- Steamed Milk Buns (open from center) with Roast Duck
- Broccoli with Mushrooms and Tofu in a delicious broth
- A bowl of plain steamed rice

The restaurant looks clean inside and out, at least for this part it is cleaner than some of the Chinese Restaurants I've been to. I do like that wait staff keeps their plates, bowls, chopsticks, spoons and forks clean. This is always a good thing and I really like how they clean the chopsticks and place them in a paper holder. Overall, very good first time experience here. The restaurant looks very spacious so this is also a good thing. Clean and spacious restaurant giving a cozy dining environment is one feature many consumers look for when they dine out.
I will be coming back for dim sum next time I am in the Sunset District. An updated review will be available once I try the dim sum menu items from here.

I like how they have photos placed in frames posted on the walls, it is a wonderful idea. Come here for dim sum or dinner and see for yourself!

Parking: Street Parking*
*Most of the spots are equipped parking meters so be prepared to have spare coins or a parking meter debit card on hand.

Public Transportation:
MUNI Routes 71 Haight Noriega on Noriega St and 29 Sunset on Sunset Blvd
author: Bennett W.

description:
How many times have you gone into a Chinese restaurant and been treated like dirt. Rude waiters and waiting forever for a glimpse of service? Well not here. The wait staff was very friendly and attentive and understands how the customer should be treated. At one point they were dragging a hose into the kitchen and it was making scraping sounds against the sides of the door and the waiter came to our table and apologized for the intrusion....... In a Chinese restaurant!!
Bravo for the service!! Very good. The food was very tasty and the flavor of the dim sum popped in all the right places. Highly recommend
author: David P.

description: The food was good but the restroom is dirty. Someone should deep clean the restroom. The waiter made sure I gave him 15% tips or higher. He came up and complain the tip is not enough.
author: Thai D.

description:
We has dim sum today. The wait for table  for 4 around noon is not bad. Go after 12:30 if you don't want to wait too long for a table. 

Food was decent. Food arrived pretty quickly. 

The 2 star review is for the bill and poor customer from the waiter and the owner who was working as the cashier today. She double charged us- our bill for four was over $100. When we alerted the waiter,   no one apologized, owner grunted and yelled. So, check your bill before paying!!
author: Julie T.

description:
Sat down on five minutes and have been waiting forever for my food....20 minutes or so

Prices seems to be like 20% more than Riverside..... Should hand gone there instead
author: william f.

description:
I have to say that S&T is one of the best dim sum places I have ever dined in. What makes S&T stand out for me is that this dim sum place is not like other ones  based on the fact that there are no ladies moving around with carts. Instead, S&T provides its customers with sheets of all the dim sum items and customers check off which items they would like and how many servings they want for their table. This ensures that you get what you want and do not have to wait around for the carts to come to you. I have had experiences where the carts never came to my table and I never got the items that I was looking for, but at S&T, you don't have to worry about that! 

The food is always fresh and delicious! My boyfriend's family usually gets the dim sum staples like xi mai and har gow, but I love their sticky rice in the banana leaf! They don't skimp out on the meats and extra fixings in the sticky rice. I've been here twice already, and everything we have ordered embodied what dim sum is all about. 

I am absolutely in love with S&T!
author: Veda T.

description: Most of the dim sum is tasty but a bit on the oily side. Green onion pancakes were too thin, didn't taste like onions (too minced up) and reeked of old oil. The wrapper for the shrimp and chives dumplings were too thick. Salt and pepper calamari was reasonably priced at under $3.00 but it didn't have the salt and pepper taste. Took them forever to take our order (the paper menu we marked up) and we had to remind them of getting us the soda we ordered. Don't think we'll be coming back, even with a health score in the 80s compared to low 70 scores at other dim sum houses.
author: Ami K.

description: I usually enjoy coming here for lunch or dinner. So I took a friend here to celebrate a special day. We ordered fish porridge and discovered a short black hair in the porridge!!!!   OMG...that is why chief needs to hair net!!!
author: Ms R.

description:
No way is this restaurant $$, because I ate a ridiculous amount and paid $12 including tip.  That is $. 

Was the food delicious?...as a non-Asian, trying to control my fat intake, and not a huge fan of oily foods...No. Not really. But as a non-Asian, with a ton of asian friends living in San Francisco, and knowing (kinda) that this is what legit Chinese food is...then yes. It is good.

But is it something spectacular? No. Not really. 
But I would stand in a long wait for them for $12 all you can eat non-buffet.
author: Julianna I.

description:
I didn't get a chance to scan all of the reviews for S&T HK, but it seems that almost 90% are about dim sum. Therefore we can conclude a few things.

- Yelpers generally care more about dim sum out of a wide array of representative Cantonese cuisine delights.

- Some might freeze panic like a deer in headlights if they had to take over the reins of ordering at the dinner table (when no dim sum is around), and thus stay in shallow waters to avoid drowning in the deeper unknown even with a GPS and scuba gear.

- S&T would be considered astronomical pricing in Chinatown or parts of Irving (which is why Ming Kee couldn't survive...old school locals preferred crappy quality and cheap pricing over paying a dollar or two more for top quality). Some probably would rather eat gourmet roach coaches, Go to MY China or Hakkasan, than spend a similar amount on a non glitzy decent Cantonese dinner. 

Listen to Susy C. Dinner here is quite da Sh&T indeed. Try to show up after 6 pm without a reservation. Maybe you'll get as far as the waiting area by the stand where you see some Hello Kitty stuffed animals and mini plush dolls. No doubt this was the handiwork of the lady boss. If you are a real a$$ FOB you will notice various framed pictures of the lady boss with various celebrities from Hong Kong who have dined at the restaurant, hung across the upper walls around the main dining room. Definitely InstaBook worthy ego boosting material. Maybe some of you out there might know who Law Kar Ying and "Fat Mama" Maria Cordero are. Oh Ed Lee ate here too.  

Very interesting that a restaurant of this stature and quality tried to open a branch in San Mateo downtown (HK Causeway Bay) and it flopped so bad, yet this place is still thriving and doing very well. Or maybe the feng shui in SM at that spot has been cursed for years.

OK too much BS...let's get to the food.

Check the live seafood tanks to give yourself an idea of what they have. Then peruse the regular menu, but I find the more effective technique is to chat with the waiter, examine what others are eating, and also scan the specials menu. There is quite a lot of variety here that can slow you down.

BBQ pork (cha siu) - arguably one of the most recognizeable of Cantonese roasties, and popular amongst expats. The rendition here is quite splendid and has all the right things going for it, such as a very natural color (no food coloring), thus more brown than red. The cut of meat resembles pork shoulder (mui tau) and has decent marbling, tender but with a good bite. The slices rest on a bed of yellow soybeans, which is a good traditional pairing. The "nam yu" sauce of the marination seemed a tad heavy, but a great effort indeed. Worthy of recommendation.

Pacific surf clam (gwai fei pong) - steamed with garlic, bean thread noodles, with soy sauce and some oil. Outperformed Brother Seafood easy, best one I'd had so far. The adductor muscle/scallop from the clam is good chit. A bit too much oil, but it was at the bottom of the plate. If they do this right, seafood should be good here too (but beware, $30/lb for a coral/sesame grouper...not cheap). Easy to see why locals just stick with salt pepper crab (even they stick with shallow waters during dinner...)

slow fire soup of the day - a small pot is enough for 4 to 5 people. Saturday night's offering was stewed with papaya (for sweetness), chicken feet (none could be seen in the soup), peanuts, pork/pork bone, and snow ear funghi. The materials are cheap but the effect is solid. Soothing on a cold evening. 

yam leaf with garlic in superior broth - always good to ask the waiter what Chinese greens are available. Stir fry with garlic is way too boring these days, and too much oil and heat can cause issues....so cooking in superior broth is the way to go. Still a bit bland? Tell them to add garlic, which is stir fried first (browned) then throw in with the veggies. Tender, moist, juicy, yet a very light crisp on the stems. 

soy sauce chicken - hint: this might be available only 6 pm or after, so ask before ordering if it is available if you arrive before 6. Ming Kee still makes the most stellar soy sauce chicken around, but until they reopen, S&T's version is still quite noteworthy indeed.

Comp house dessert - red bean soup. Slightly diluted in texture, but it turns out it was because of the ginger juice added which gave the flavor profile an extra dimension. Decent dried orange peel flavor. Great way to end the meal.

Good stuff. I'll be back. An easy 4.25 stars for me.

Fortunately the lady boss doesn't need the celeb photo shots taken inside the restaurant, to prove that S&T is indeed da Sh&T.
author: Ken K.

description:
Everyone seems to be complaining about the service here. It's a Chinese restaurant, people! Don't think of it as bad service. Think of it as an authentic experience. 

Been coming here for years with family. Very good dim sum, especially the siu mai. Non dim sum fare is also quite good. Definitely worth trying if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Ada C.

description:
Being Chinese and having gone to Chinese restaurants all my life, I do not have high expectations for service from Chinese servers, but today's experience hit a new low.  So low, in fact, I will not be going back.

I came for lunch today with my 82 yo mother.  Even past 1 pm, the restaurant was almost full.  I didn't mind being given a table way in the corner near their take out counter next door.  I've been coming long enough to know this table is mostly used as a staging area for that takeout counter.

What was a problem, however, was that the utility table had edges that made it look like it had been a teething toy for a lion.  As if the discolored table top weren't bad enough, the edges of the table facing the diners were chipped to the point where there were 2 to 3 inch chunks missing, exposing some grey matter underneath.

Even then, I was OK with it as long as they threw a white tablecloth or square of white butcher paper over it, with which almost every other table in the restaurant was covered.

The server's response?  No need, because we wipe off those tables.

My response?  We can take our business elsewhere to a restaurant that has some minimal standards.

I've been to HK Seafood many times over the decades, but I won't be going back.  There are too many good restaurants in SF to go to one that treats its 82 yo customers badly.
author: Susan C.

description: Food is slightly above average, prices are too high, and staff is mostly rude. This part of the sunset needs more good food options, this place is not worth it.
author: M E.

description:
Yum yum dim sum in my tum tum. :)

This is my family's favorite dim sum place in the Sunset. I came here on Memorial Day with a friend for lunch. It was delicious as usual. For two people, we split about 6 dishes and the total was $35 -- not bad at all! 

Admittedly, not a dim sum expert and I get the pretty basic dishes, but they are absolutely delicious here -- siu mai, har gow, fried shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings (did I mention I like shrimp?). Siu mai is probably my favorite. Great flavor. I also got the chow fun which I found a bit average.

The location is in the busy, Asian area of Noriega, so prepare to fight for a parking spot. The restaurant itself is your run of the mill Chinese place. It's usually pretty packed, but the wait is surprisingly pretty short, especially if you have a small group.

I highly recommend this place for dim sum!
author: Greg J.

description:
S&T's prices rivals that of Koi Palace and HK Lounge, and so I expect them to deliver Dim Sum of that caliber. Or maybe even something close.

But S&T is not even in the same league. There's no shame in making Dim Sum in the minor leagues, but it becomes a problem when they charge major league prices. We ordered more than 15 plates and couldn't find one that could be considered as delicious. Their dumplings instantly falls apart to the touch of chopsticks. Most of the time, I would be eating the Shrimp separately from the skin. Most of the things were also very bland. I'm not sure if I was there to taste Dim Sum or Kikkoman's soy sauce.

But this is a very well decorated place. The owner is also pretty boss because he/she got a lot of pictures with celebrities. I just wouldn't come here just because I can pay the same money for Koi Palace.
author: Ringo M.

description:
I came here for dim sum a few times during the week. Their food is good and they offer a variety of items. If you don't speak or read Chinese, you can still eat here because they have English on their menu. The service is very good and the food comes out quickly. 

One of the items I was super excited about was the "low sa bao" (spilling sand bun) but when I opened the bun, there wasn't much yolk spilling out. It still tasted good. The Portugese egg tart wasn't as good as the ones I've eaten in Macau. It was basically an egg tart that got burned. I really liked their "ha gau." They give 4 pieces and there was a lot of shrimp inside.

Hanging on the wall in the restaurant, they have photos of the owner with Hong Kong celebrities. I'm not sure when those photos were taken but they look pretty recent (photos haven't faded yet). Iif you're a fan of HK dramas, you might want to come check this place out. Raymond Lam is one of those celebs.
author: Anna F.

description:
I have come here a few times for dim sum. It was just okay from what I remember, but it's best to come here for dinner.

Ordering large banquet dinners family style is the way to go. Way more economical. 

My friends and I love the salted egg w/ pumpkin crab here. Oh lawd have mercy on my beating heart , for it will probably stop soon. 
Crab that's coated in salted egg yolk. When it's deep fried, it makes the exterior gritty and crispy. So delicious. Plenty of deep fried pumpkin that adorns it as well. 
My face probably starts brewing zits the moment it touches my lips but it's so delicious.
author: Susy C.

description:
How often do you get to have dimsum for lunch during the week? I admit it's rare, but as my brother-in-law's only day off, it's a nice opportunity to spend time with him and the baby. Another friend joined us as well, and three men and a baby were off to find some dumplings at S&T.

We ordered a variety of items including pork spare ribs, Chinese broccoli, fried tofu, fried rice, and many more. My favorite was definitely the fried donuts wrapped in rice noodles. So delicious! Overall I enjoyed the meal though it might have been a little on the greasy side.

Parking is tough on Noriega so it's best to park on the side streets instead. Service was ok but not fantastic, but what Chinese place is? I think I prefer Daly City dimsum to here, but as a super local place, I would come back.

Food: 7/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: Typical chinese restaurant with a notch up with decor.  Known best for their soy sauce chicken.  If you are with a big party, be sure to pre-order in advance as they do sell quick and run out.  Prices are average along the others on Noriega.
author: JADE L.

description:
They know how to dim sum. This isnt my most favourite place to get dim sum but its near my house and they make really good shrimp dumplings. Im not talking about har gaou but like the deep fried ones. Ugh. So good. 

I have been here several times and I dont have any complaints. 

They got all the basics down. Har gaou, siu mai, cheung fun, all dat good stuff. 

This place doesnt do the cart rolling around and you pick what you want. There's a menu with all the stuff listed and you write down what quantity of the item you want. I dont really think that the menu is that english friendly but the staff isnt reluctant to help.
author: Becca W.

description:
Went here because people rated it one of the best dim sum place but really it sucked. The food wasn't good and came out cold. 

It was also the last thing my boyfriend and I are before heading back to seattle. We started feeling sick after a couple of hours of being there. We were on and off the toilet all night.  Think it gave us food poisoning.

If you're looking for a good dim sum place... Go to Hong Kong lounge 2.
author: Tina T.

description:
Service is horrible... 

Food was good, I love their peking duck and dim sum plates. It was a bit expensive but still very yummy.
author: Ames A.

description: Services is about like any other places. I came here for dim sum and it turned out great. Fresh and hot...
author: Willie W.

description:
It's a local dim sum restaurant for me.  No frills.  I would give it 3.5 but I don't have that option.  It's not Koi Palace but it's doable.  The dim sum came out piping hot and fresh.  It claims made to order.  

Dinner is good, too.  I have no complaints.  It's not a fancy restaurant so if you're expecting that, don't eat there.  

I have no complaints.  Typical service from a Chinese restaurant.
author: Ernest Y.

description: Good dim sum at good prices! At little slow but the restaurant is spacious. No carts though
author: Amy Y.

description:
I love the freshness of everything here. The best Cantonese food in US for the entire decade I'm here. 

Gwa Fey chicken - the quality of the chicken is comparable to Qing yuan chicken. Low fat, smooth skin, muscled chicken meat and good sauce. I wish the sauce is less salty though. $10.50
Gwa fey clam - steamed with silky noodles and garlic. $6.95 each. So tasty and fresh. 
Steamed cod fish - the meat is so fluffy compared to frozen fish that is solid. It's "hung Lung cod". The bad thing is that they didn't tell me this is $23.5 per pound. So ended up to be $48 for the fish. But so good and fresh. 
Hour-cooked soup - not greasy at all. Tonight is pork chop with Chinese squash. I drank 4 bowls of it! $6.95. 
Complimentary green bean dessert - good and not sweet at all. 

Love everything but fish was pricey. My stomach is very happy :)
author: Ashley C.

description:
I just had a horrible experience here for dim sum.  When paying our bill, I saw a mistake and went up to the front to correct it.  The lady at the counter who is the owner started to scream at me for no reason.

The mistake wasn't her fault but there was no reason to scream at your customers.  My lunch was ruined and a horrible start to my day.
author: Stanley T.

description: I mean, the dim sum here is nothing special, but it was adequately tasty and filling. Plus, everything came out fresh and hot out of the kitchen so at least there's that. Also, not the most expensive dim sum I've found. Go elsewhere for better dim sum or come here for a solid meal.
author: Ruobin W.

description: Great place for excellent dim sum. Always hot and fresh. Price wise it is in the mid range but you won't be disappointed with the food. You can even get dim sum to go from the to go counter. Whenever I am in this area I make it a point to stop by for lunch or dinner.
author: Rodo A.

description:
Came here for dim sum and it was not very good. 

The soup dumplings (XLB) had no soup in them and they were really small and shriveled up. In fact, they looked quite sad. 

Their shiu mai was also very disappointing. On the menu it's listed as "shiitake mushroom shiu mai" but the mushrooms were nowhere to be found. Instead, it was replaced with excess oil and soggy wrapping.

The rest of the dishes were okay - xo noodles, deep fried taro balls, chives and shrimp dumplings.

For dessert, we ordered their deep fried almond balls with egg yolk. It was interesting... it's pretty much exactly how it sounds. Sweet egg yolk in the middle of a sticky/mochi type ball, and covered with almond slices and deep fried. It's not bad, but at first the taste and texture is very confusing. 

If I'm going to be driving out  this far for dim sum, I'd rather go to Hong Kong Lounge II which is much closer and much better.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
First timer here from LA. Came here for my gf's birthday dinner since it was nearby to her house. 

The parking situation wasn't too bad since we were able to find a spot right in front of the restaurant. 

The food was ok; we ordered five dishes. First one was walnut shrimp; the shrimp tasted alright, wasn't too amazing. I had better walnut shrimp in LA. Second one was ong choy aka morning glory. For $14.95, the quantity of vegetables was absolutely amazing. It also helps when it tastes good too. Third dish was sweet and sour pork. I liked this dish as it complemented well with steamed white rice. Fourth dish was mixed veggies with squid; the celery was a bit hard to chew otherwise it was a tasty dish. The last dish we ordered was a vermicelli hot pot with veggies. I didn't believe the dish looked appealing to eat since it lacked color. Not sure if I'll order next time. 

The dessert was ok, wasn't the best green bean dessert I ever had. I might come back next time when I am in town.
author: Frank L.

description: This restaurant is underrated. My crew and I have been here a few times and we never dissapponte once!!! Must try Ox tail Stew and Special House Chicken. Their dimsum is really delicious too! The man here was so funny and helpful. We asked him about what to order and he honestly gave some comments about the bad dishes (that we almost order) and recommend us to oder the good dishes (not about pricing different because the one he recommended actually was cheaper). Had a great din din here, def come back
author: Nga N.

description:
Recollections of stops at S&T always boil down to this.  When I bring someone here, that person always asks this first.  Who is this short haired Asian lady pictured with a bunch of random folk framed across the walls of the whole restaurant?  To most people, one of the only recognizable faces is San Francisco's current mayor, Ed Lee.  The others are an assortment of Chinese film and television stars (and some singers).  The short haired lady is either the owner or manager.  

On the weekends, this place is a mad house during the dim sum hours.  When the table is finally ready, don't expect to pick from dim sum carts because there are none.  They have their list of dim sum to choose from and you'll tag the ones wanted with the numerical quantity desired.  Below I made a mini set of items for first time goers of S&T:
 
GET IT!
*Pan fried taro cake - My favorite dim sum item here.  They make it different than a lot of places.  The taro cake is actually made up of shaved up shards of taro and then pan fried.  Can you say "yummy taro in my belly?" 

TRY IT!
*Scallop dumplings - Here they're formed in a shape similar to a large tortellini.  The wrapping of the dumpling is a little thick, but the mixture of scallops and yellow chives make up for it.  Wish there was more scallop though.    

*Steamed Chicken Feet - I don't always order this due to the oily nature.  What am I kidding myself?  Most dim sum is fatty in some way or another anyway.  They cut them into smaller pieces.  Two benefits come from this:  the juice gets sucked into the feet more and also they are easier to eat.    

AVOID!
*Green onion pancake - I couldn't hold back my yearning for a green onion pancake the last time.  I understand this is not supposed to be their forte, but come on.  Order at your own risk.  Mistake was made and I'm passing the message along.  

*"Special Order" chow mein - Periodically, the dim sum servers will come around with "specials" that come with a "special" price.  One of them is the chow mein and you can order it by the bucket at a dim sum-to-go place that'll taste comparable.  

Compared to some other dim sum offerings in the local vicinity, they definitely do a better job than their immediate peers.  When compared to a larger spectrum, S&T is a passable dim sum spot.  The restaurant also has a to-go dim sum area for a bite on the run.  Personally I wouldn't mind driving further for some better dim sum.  In a pinch, I wouldn't ever complain about coming back here.  Reasonably priced with an equivalent quality one would expect.
author: Arnold T.

description:
Was passing through town in this part of San Francisco and felt like having Dim Sum.

I stopped in with my brother and sister for a quick bite. The selection is about average for price and quality. The service and atmosphere definitely needs improvement for sure... But I guess most Asian place aren't known for services but for the foods.

Typical Chinese Restaurant in the area compared with others I've been to in San Francisco China Town. 

No cart Dim Sum... All on menu which makes it easier to place your order all at once.
author: v v.

description: The lady boss there is horrible, the worst customer service I have seen so far, don't go there unless you want her to yell at you, customers should always right, remember her face, she posted her ugly pictures on the wall with super star from H.K. Bad bad bad customer service
author: Vivian W.

description:
Came here for dinner on a weds night.

I had a fresh fish that I planned to bring to another restaurant but it was closed.

I asked the guy if it was ok for him to cook it and he said sure.

 oyster tofu claypot was good
steamed pork cake with salted egg . It was good
Our steamed fish came out perfect 
We had steamed shrimp it was good but I think it was like $38/lb came out to 8 pieces
Crab meat fish maw soup was nice and hot
Chinese broccoli was also good

The dinner chef knows what he's doing
The lady boss was nice to us too.

I would come back for dinner if I was around the neighborhood
author: DOM d.

description: Food was okay. Roast duck was miles behind Cheung Hing. Steamed spare ribs were very salty. Wait staff were not exact rude but were amateurish to say the least - what the Chinese would say diao er lang dang, if not liu li liu qi. I saw one of them arguing with a guy saying he didn't tip enough. They went back and forth for 2 full minutes. Really, business is so bad you have to beg for tips now?! What the hey? And the boss lady - yuck!
author: YM L.

description:
Came here for CNY dim sum today.  The wait to be seated was long and ridiculous, but our order came out pretty fast so we were happy since we were all starving.  Their HK Crispy Noodles were pretty good.  The shu mai, har how, sticky rice, fried taro dumplings, shrimp rice noodles, pork buns, and XLB were all pretty good.  Not the best, but decent.  The turnip cake was a little too mushy so I would skip that one.  They even had Portuguese egg tarts, which is pretty rare at a dim sum place so we ordered it.  It wasn't too bad, but the inside was pretty soft.  At least the flavors were there.  

Don't expect great service here.  We were here last night for CNY eve dinner and one of the server spilled quite a bit of sauce on cousin's jacket and all he said was sorry.  Didn't even make an effort to offer dry cleaning!
author: Erica S.

description:
the bitter melon beef dish, fish and tofu in a clay pot, white chicken with ginger dip on the side, any vegetable dish is a hit like chinese spinach stir fried, duck, crab, beef cube dish, chinese broccoli, duck tongue.....  all excellent, on dinner menu.

Lunch items, all is good, for typical dim sum stuff, but favorite include the beans underlain sweet pork dish (Cha Siu).  Flaky dessert durian, any long noodle wrapped with shrimp, beef, or dough.

It's not terribly hard to find parking.  There is parking along the side streets, and depending on when you go, you don't need to pay for parking.
author: J. W.

description: Yummy dim sum and dinner. Prices in the mid-range. Get the soy sauce chicken...it's really good! Almost every table had it during dinner. Can be a half order if you have a smaller group. Sometimes they run out or not available for some reason, so call ahead. The BBQ pork is also very good. We tend to order items not on the menu, but everything still comes out fresh and tasty. Service is good when not busy. Can't wait to go back! Parking is pretty easy on a weeknight. Gets crowded for dim sum and dinner on weekends.
author: Lil D.

description:
We had dinner here tonight.  Portions are pretty big.  The pluses:

-bathroom is clean and is well stocked.  They even supply toilet seat tissue (this is a must in my book).

-honey walnut shrimp was good

-service is better than the average chinese restaurant

-loved all the pictures of HK celebrities with the owner, who somehow doesn't quite face the camera in any of the pics.

Minuses

-some dishes were undercooked.  The fried fish filet came out undercooked and red.  The flesh was still stuck to the bone.  We really couldn't send it back cuz the waiter parsed it for us.  How do you refry that?

-lamb stew could use 30 more minutes in the pot.  The lamb was tough but it was tasty.

-fried calamari was pasty looking.  Not golden brown like you see at other restaurants.   There was also too much batter on the calamari.

I think if they cook the food well, they can be very successful.  Impatience doesn't really work for a chinese restaurant.
author: Wendy H.

description:
ABC's BEWARE!  

This San Francisco native ABC gets treated like dirt. Just because I'm not a fast orderer, flashing a Rolex nor go scurrying around like a chicken with their head cut off you get treated like dirt. 

The four of us went to the back room and the hostess (if you want to call her that) flipped the menus on the table and scurried away.  OK, what's the matter? Too ABC for you all?  All four of us are ABC . . . well EXCUSE ME! 

So the waiter comes right after that and asks what type of tea to we want.  We haven't even sat down. The wife orders tea and you'd think they have to get the leaves shipped from China. Soon the tea comes out and we haven't finished marking down the dim sum when the waiter stands by the table and grabs the other ticket assumingly to write down orders that are not on the dim sum menu. So he goes away and returns after he serves the entire restaurant.  FINALLY the order goes in.

Now the food: from someone who grew up in Chinatown, the food is passable but not fantastic. The various dim sum items came out quickly and as soon as one dish was empty, somebody scoops it away. We ordered beef chow fun and for the prices they charge, it lacked taste, the beef was chewy and you'd think that there was a ration on the fun noodles.  I've seen bigger and tastier chow fun orders from the dive on Taraval. Oh but wait, this is supposed to be a fancy place.  Sorry, not impressed.

So why do I come here? We take our guests here since they want to go up the street to Chung HIng, the bank, Safeway and get fresh produce. The prices are not cheap and a bit on the higher side for this dive.  Ok - ok - ok.  Sorry for the rant but that's how I feel. If you are a non-ABC or a native from China, you'd probably get better service from the staff kissing up to you.  Hate to say it, but I get better service from the DMV.
author: Stefan L.

description: Food's pretty good. Not bad at all. Funny waiter! If you understand Chinese, you might laugh all night
author: ABC Z.

description:
I had lunch and ate won-ton noodle soup at S&T Hong Kong Restaurant today around 12 noon. 

At other nearby Chinese eating joints in the same neighborhood, the same won-ton noodle soup around this vicinity usually goesfor $5.95-$6.95.

I was charged $12.95 for the same won-ton noodle. 

Lesson learned:

1)  I should have asked the price before ordering. 
Since I was not ordering something extravagant, I assumed the price would be similar to other restaurants nearby.

2)   I should have stuck to my favorites eating joints elsewhere in the same neighborhood.

I cannot help but feel that the restaurant waiter purposely charged me more than double trying to make a quick buck.

I will never visit this restaurant ever again.

PS: I am not Chinese.
author: Sachi N.

description: I've been coming to this restaurant for over twenty years and have never been disappointed. Great dim sum and courteous service.
author: H. S.

description:
Came on new years day group of 2. People who came after us were done eatting before we were seated. Will never return. 
Edit: waited 2 hours before leaving, unseated
author: Wesley H.

description:
WTF are they doing back there...shrimping?...slaughtering pigs, chicken, cows for our food? Starving enquiring minds want to know...

As we sat there ravenous with our stomach growling, these were the questions running through our minds as we waited an HOUR for our food, yes, ONE HOUR!

On Saturday, 8.13.11, my friends and I came to S&T for dim sum (it was my idea to come here *sigh*) at 1:30 PM. Surprisingly there was no wait for a table of six. There's no dim sum carts at S&T; they have a paper menu which you just mark off which dim sum plates you want. They do have the ladies bring food trays around though it was not very often and in the 1.5 hours we were there, they only brought out two items.

P R I C E S
A little more expensive than most dim sum places and a notch cheaper than Koi's though the quality is not as good. 
*$2.50 Small (e.g. dumplings)
*$3.20 Medium (e.g. buns)
*$4 Large (e.g. meat dishes)

They charge $1/person for tea. 

F O O D
*HAI BO (Fried Shrimp Ball) - 4 STARS: Warm, crunchy and succulently moist inside. 

*HAI GOW (Shrimp Dumpling) - 3.5 STARS: Filled with tender sweet shrimp with a not too thick skin. 

*SIU MAI (Pork Dumpling) - 3.5 STARS: Savory, tender and juicy.

*LUILIAN PAO FU (Durian Puffs) - 3.5 STARS: Served warm, the puffs were crisp and flakey and filled with "a pungent scent of a used jock strap sitting in butt curry" as my friend described it. As the only durian lover in the table, needless to say, it was ALL mine!

*FUNG ZHAO (Chicken Feet) - 3 STARS: Soft and gelatinous. 

*CHA SIU BAO (Baked BBQ Pork Buns) - 3 STARS: OVERRATED. Yes, it was crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside, but there wasn't much cha siu in it. The Cha Siu Bao at HK Lounge is WAY BETTER!

*NGAU YUK MAI (Steamed Beef Balls) - 3 STARS: Moist and juicy but lacked softness. 

*CHEONG FUN (Steamed Noodle Rolls w/ Shrimp, Beef, Donut) - 3 STARS: Noodles were a bit too thick. My least fav was the beef as it was more like a log of beef. 

*PAI GWAT (Steamed Spareribs) - 3 STARS: More cartilage than meat.

*SUP CHOW NGAU HAW ("Wet" Beef Chow Fun) - 3 STARS: Gravy had a gloppy consistency; too much cornstarch.

*FU PEI GUEN (Steamed Tofu Skin Roll) - 2 STARS: Savory, though veggies were mushy and it was filled with MSG.  

*WU GOK (Fried Taro Dumplings) - 2 STARS: The exterior wasn't lightly crunchy and the taro had a texture of play dough. 

*XIAO LONG BAO (Shanghai Dumpling): I didn't try this one though my friend said there was NO soup in the XLB. What's a XLB without soup?

*YEUNG HAI KIM (Stuffed Crab Claw):  Didn't try it.

*HAM SUI GOK (Fried Meat Dumplings): Didn't try it. 

*NAI WONG BOLO BAO (Custard Filled Pineapple Bun) - Didn't try it.

Overall, the food was "ok" but NOTHING really stood out to warrant a visit back. 

S E R V I C E
Sh*tty service is expected at Asian restaurants, but one good thing is the food tends to come out quickly. NOT at S&T though, service was painstakingly S-L-O-W! Since when does it take ONE HOUR to get your food at a Chinese restaurant that is NOT even busy?!?!? TOTALLY INEXCUSABLE! We asked several times on the status of our food and we got the same BS answer every time, "Shou Lai Ah" (It's coming). 

A M B I A N C E / D É C O R
Several steps above your hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant that "seems" clean with the crisp white linens but I can't get over the disgusting brown and green mold surrounding the fish tanks. I can't imagine what's lurking in the back. GROSS!

P A R K I N G
Easy metered parking and fairly easy residential parking.

Now I know what S&T stands for: "SUCKS & TERRIBLE".
author: Cherylynn N.

description: The service was awful here. I can speak Chinese and communicate fluently with the waiters here so I know it is not a language barrier. So if you don't speak Chinese, forget about it. You will never get anything you ask for. We asked for ice waters, no ice waters. We asked for soy sauce and chili sauce, after the 5th-6th time, we finally got it and half our dim sum was finished.
