Here's a tip, if you don't want your customers asking you for condiments, then put them on the table. It's really simple and many restaurants adopt that practice. It's not rocket science. The part that makes this to be an unbelievable experience is when I just wanted to double check that our order went in because when I placed it, the waiter was all excited to see this kid walk in the restaurant so I thought he may have forgotten it. In my most polite Chinese voice, I just simply asked if the order was in and he said if you can't wait then box up your stuff and you can go. Omg! Needless to say, I got the tab, cancel those items, and that cocky waiter can get his big fat $0 tip for his poor attitude! We wanted to tell the manager/owner about our experience and she said she wasn't the person to talk to and we were like okay then why is your picture framed all over the restaurant with celebrities? Ok I see they could care less. I hope they enjoy the regular local customers because that is the only reason they are still in business. Their luck will run out eventually. It's SF, they won't survive. This place too cray cray for me.
author: Wendy L.

description:
After spending all day shopping around downtown and then taking a 45 minute bus ride back to the apartment, my roommate was really craving some wontons, so we came to S&T Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant, where she'd had wontons with her dad before. We got there at around 8PM, and there were a good amount of people eating there, with a few large parties too. 

The food: we ordered a seafood wonton soup, mapo tofu, and a spicy eggplant with fish claypot. Overall I think the food was average; perhaps not the most authentic of Chinese foods, but definitely filling and tasty. I was pleasantly surprised with the wonton soup; I was honestly just expecting some wontons floating around in soup, but it came stocked full of seafood, vegetables, and large wontons. 

The waiter who was serving us (we never got his name) was really great too. He joked with us while getting us the check, and then after we stupidly left the restaurant without our $20 worth of boxed food, ran out into the street to find us. We had already gone by then, but luckily remembered and turned back. He had saved the food and joked that he had a heart attack trying to find us. So nice!
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Decent dimsum was good..

I found service very good compared to most Asian restaurants.

Nice and spacious between each table and I found the place relatively clean which was good.

I would go back!
author: Sharon L.

description:
Longest wait EVER to get dim sum!

Our party of 7 came here Saturday afternoon at 1:30pm.  To my surprise, we didn't have to wait for a table and were seated immediately.  

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Dim sum carts do not come around, you mark the paper menu
*It took an hour for all our dishes to come out (yes, I was angry)
*Prices are a bit above average (we paid $20 a person)
*Unfriendly service (yes, I was complaining our food hasn't all came out)  
*$1/person for tea (apparently this is standard?)
*Dim sum stops being served at 2:30pm (we didn't get our food until AFTER they closed)
*Seriously, IT TOOK AN HOUR FOR OUR DISHES TO ALL COME OUT!

FOOD:
Average, I think I was too mad to even care, all I wanted was food.

WORTH TRYING:
*Steamed tofu skin rolls
*Fried shrimp balls
*Deep fried crab & shrimp balls
*Pineapple buns with custard inside

AVOID:
*Shanghai dumplings - there was no broth at all

PARKING:
Street metered parking.  My friend and I had an easy time finding parking.

If I wanted to waste an hour, I'd rather have been standing around waiting for a table at Koi Palace.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Not all Dim Sum is created equal... 

Not all Asians are friendly and welcoming to White people who look like they forgot where their tourist bus drop off point is.... 

This is an incredible Chinese restaurant, we arrived during the Saturday lunch rush, packed, people waiting on the sidewalk and corner to get in. My sister went in and got us a number, the hostess said it would be about 20 minutes. 

We waited..... and waited.... then the little one had to go potty, so we walked in the packed lobby, I asked the hostess where the bathrooms were and she directed us to the restroom. The hostess was polite and gracious, she could have said 'restroom is for customers only' which I kind of thought she would say since it has been said to me before and she didn't know we were there waiting for a table. 

After we used the bathroom I told my sister how nice the hostess was and my sister said they were really nice to her when she went in to get our number. 

We ordered baked BBQ pork buns which the boyz loved, 3 orders of Har Gow, Shrimp noodles, salt and pepper squid, black bean ribs, and a Chou fried rice which I have never had before that is now a must order every where I go. We ordered other things off the tray as the ladies walked by, no wheeled carts here. All of it was wonderful. They even have a little Dim Sum togo counter, with a line out the door for that. 

Service is fast and friendly, they are just the a excellent Dim Sum place that they are packed with people and definitely worth the wait! 

I found this place on yelp. Thanks my fellow yelpers!
author: Serra S.

description: I haven't had chinese food for a week and I was hoping this would satisfy my cravings but blehhhh.  The food is bland and boring. It didn't look like the picture in the menu book
author: Julie L.

description:
This place even charges $1.25 per person for cup of water, never seen that in anywhere else. 

This is ridiculous!! 

Never come back again, cheap place!!

Would give minus score if there is any.
author: Yiping W.

description:
The restaurant could be cleaner.  Seems a bit run-down.  Restroom cleanliness was fine.  Waiter was friendly and funny (no name badge so can't give him credit).  The food was pretty good flavor-wise, but there were some unexpected findings:

- Shells in fried noodles but there wasn't supposed to be any shellfish/seafood.  Did they reuse the same wok without cleaning it first?
- Toothpick in food.
author: Amanda B.

description:
I like the food. It was good. But the service was lousy!!
I complained to the owner Miss Choi about the service. She was sincerely apologize for what had happened from the waiter name Danny .(Paul Yee Fung) . It was the most uncomfortable remark he made in front of the all the guests. 
m
Below is the letter from his explanation which is not quite acceptable to me. However I hope he is truly sincerely apologize and correct his behavior. 



From: "Paulyeefung" paulyeefung@yahoo.com

Sent: Sunday, July 21, 2013 9:44:10 PM
Subject: Sorry!

       , ,.
author: Marina T.

description:
Nom nom nom! This is my family's favorite favorite dim-sum place. They have a "to-go" mini store to the right of the entrance where you can just buy take-out dim sum if you want to skip the wait. Usually my family chooses to do that but we decided to dine in on Saturday. 

We came around 1:30-2 so we totally skipped the lunch wait which was great because this place is usually super packed with a crowd outside. S&T stopped doing the dim sum carts like they used to (maybe because the restaurant is small or they added tables) but they do the paper order where you check off the stuff you want. This was particularly difficult when I came with my bf last time because we didn't know the english translations and only knew the food by sight (haha)

But this came I came with family and we ordered chicken feet, square taro cakes, sew mai, dan tats, rice wrapped in bamboo leaf, sesame balls with taro inside, lobster chow mein and ha churng. Plates and plates of dim sum filled the table. The food came out fast and we had no complaints.

 I'm still going to keep coming here but most likely ordering out next door  if the wait is long! :)
author: Vikki K.

description: Omg soooo good! Get the steamed pork buns! The fried beef dumplings were yummy. Such sweet service too. Good pricing.
author: Jenn R.

description:
ok... food is alright. service is metiocre. great selections but it seemed as if every single dish was oily as hell. kind of gross... makes you want to stop eating after awhile. i'm taking away one star because they pissed me off with not knowing how to follow some rather simple instructions.

so... if you're chinese like i am, you KNOW that there's always an issue when the bill comes. our crazy families always fight over the check and it's a bit embarassing. anyway, i was smart... my fiance slyly handed them his card before all the food came out. his instructions said... charge this table to this card. my fiance and i just wanted to do something nice for the family. ummm... then the bill came at the end of our meal. my dad and i were fighting over the bill. apparently, the idiots didn't know how to follow the simple ass instructions. ughhhhh.... ANNOYED.
author: Ann T.

description:
The only decent dim sum place in the whole Sunset district. The place is getting a low rating because of how dirty the whole place is and how there is a ton of MSG in all their foods. 

You will be drinking at least a gallon of water after eating here.
author: M C.

description: Everything was delicious! We think we had an entree skipped, but the food was great. Fit well for large party
author: Brittany C.

description: This restaurant seems like another Hong Kong Chinese restaurant. It has a decent interior and enough space to sit many people. The service is good for dim sum. It's really busy on the weekend for dim sum. I've only had dim sum and never have anything to complain about. I like other noodle dishes. I think it's worth going to every now and then. XLB's are okay, fried squid really good, pumpkin fries were fun.
author: Denise C.

description:
Insanely expensive Geoduck! I ordered a Geoduck there for $84 before tax. CRAZY! But it was delicious! worth $84.. not really. i expeced this to be expensive but $84 for a dish is a lot! 

Came here for dinner with my family. We ordered the family set dinner. Every dish was huge. Food in general is really good. I just remember the salt and pepper ribs was a bit on the salty side. Other then that everything was very good.

We had enough even for lunch for the people that had to bring lunch. Even the leftovers were yummy! 

Thinking about the geoduck, nicely steamed with soysauce makes me salivate...yummmmmm
author: Tiffany C.

description: Dim sum is awesome here.. we had fried chicken wings, pork rib porridge, rice roll with bitter mellon, fried bean curd paper wrap shrimp and some other stuff. All were really good and food came fast.
author: Cindy M.

description:
Just ate here recently for my grandmas birthday. It was delicious !!! Everything from the banquet we ordered was super fresh and presented in a timely fashion!

I was just so amazed at how fresh the cold cut appetizer was! Usually, the bbq pork is a bit darker and dry and the jellyfish is chewy, however, here it was bright red and a beautiful gold color and had a slight crunchy texture to it! Highly recommended !

I cPretty much all the seafood is recommended! I have never been so impressed before. 

Service here is beyond the call of duty. We went on a Saturday night which is probably their busiest but they still managed to get everything we asked for in less than 3 minutes. They even changed out plates for us. They even presented us with mango moochis for my grandmas birthday. Each mochi was made with fresh mangos, a delightful way to end the night. 

This has been one of my most pleasant dining experiences at a Chinese  restaurant.
author: Sue T.

description: The food was seriously mediocre. That's saying something cause I LOVE food and it's hard to get it wrong for my taste buds. We ordered the ong choy, ginger chicken, tofu and fish, swab, and shrimp. Maybe trying other dishes will change my mind on the food. The server recognized my grandparents so he was extremely polite and respectful. I would mention his name, but I forgot. The ambiance was delightful! Although, there is this fish tank towards the back of the restaurant that is leaking water. Personally, I don't like that because people can easily trip! Especially elderlies like my grandma. I hope they fix it before I comeback to try the rest of the menu with my family
author: Stephanie W.

description:
My fam and I came here for a Christmas Eve meal. We tend to celebrate the holidays on the eve because we want to avoid the crowded restaurants. So, by showing up at 6pm, we avoided the rush, and people started lining up at around 6:30pm. 

For a family of four, we ordered the $88/ 4 entree special. It included fake shark fin soup, fried pigeon, stir-fry veggies and beef, and a steamed fish. I always detest ordering the combo specials because they tend to come with some not-as-appetizing dishes. In this case, I could have gone without the fake shark fin soup and the stir-fry veggies and beef. They were simple and ordinary. At least the pigeon dish lived up to its name as being a Shek-Ki delicacy, and the steam fish was flavorful and light. 

Also, we added a $25 lobster noodle as my mother raved about it. She said, from her previous visit, the lobster noodles included a big and succulent lobster and her foreign visitor ate it like a barbarian. But this time, my mother was wrong as the lobster was small. Despite it size, this dish was still good. My favorite part was substituting the ee mein with thin egg noodles. The thin egg noodles soaked in lobster juice and became my favorite part of the meal. 

I would def come back to this restaurant, either for dim sum or dinner. After all, I have been to this restaurant location countless times, even when they switched countless owners in the past 20 years.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Food was fresh and hot. Missed the carts, but could figure out the order by the description. They charge for tea and water. Recommend go to the store next door first. No carts. Bathrooms gross. Go before you come here.
author: C J.

description: Responsive staff, bright and airy with windows on two sides.  Avoid the table for two nearest the bathroom because it's hard to flag down the staff from there in case you need anything.   Dim sum came quickly after ordering on the paper menu.  Price is medium, definitely not what I'd consider cheap eats.  But, you pay for the table service.  Tea is $1.25 per person. Also high.    Egg custard tart had good crust, but some lumpy crunch bits that while not harmful didn't feel like the right texture.
author: Thom S.

description:
Sunday morning dim sum, mMm yes please!

Yeah - the food. always find myself ordering the soy sauce chow mein since it comes out almost right away. lobster dumplings with the mayo is a no brainer.

Meh - the service. never had an issue with the staff being rude or painfully slow. can't say they go above and beyond but I've come to not expect too much from chinese restaurants. 

Eh - the wait/parking. like everyone else has noted, the wait (to be seated) can pretty bad, especially on sundays. add the fact that parkings sparse around these parts, you're making for some antsy patrons.

I've been coming here for close to 15 years now, and through the many management changes, it's still the dim sum place of choice.
author: Albert T.

description:
This is for their dinner.

The food here used to be good. It used to be fresh, flavorful and we would be able to get unique items. Not so much anymore. The menu was kind of blasee and unimpressive. While their soy sauce chicken is good, it's not worth the $30. They even messed up on honey walnut shrimp, how can you do that?? I guess what I really wanted was foie gras, and alas have to go to Kitchen in Milbrae for that.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
TERRIBLE SERVICE!!! The waiters were rude and served us like there was something up their rear. We had to constantly ask in order to get any service. They were slow in almost every way imaginable. On top of that; they got our order wrong. PATHETIC!! The only good thing was their food; but their rude and poor attention to customer service made me drop them from the list. NOT PEOPLE FRIENDLY! NEVER GOING BACK!! 

I do NOT recommend S&T Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant to anyone!
author: Gnemok Y.

description:
Celebrated my aunt's 70th birthday here. We brought our own Sou Bao because we didn't know it complementary for large birthday groups so they gave us a $20 certificate! Long life noodles looked kind of plain and unappetizing but they were actually flavorful.

Like any other Chinese restaurant, expect greasy food! Food here is better than most Chinese restaurants. Just look at the HK celebrities displayed on the wall. Raymond Lam, Bernice Liu.... Mayor Ed Lee?
author: Pansy L.

description:
Went here for Dim Sum this morning (saturday morning) with my aunt and mom.. it was alright..

Dim sum was a bit overpriced I thought, the service was definitely questionable. I watched a table behind us leave, and watched a waitress storm from the room yelling that someone had left! Did anyone know where the lady went?! Kind of scary.

It's in a good location... close to my mom's house and parking seemed better than irving or clement st., but.. eh. I'd rather go to Good Luck over on Clement.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
5 Reasons to Never Eat at this Place 

background: firstly, I am a former food writer for AsianWeek in San Francisco + live/eat/travel/work between Hong Kong and San Francisco.  I know my food from the operations restaurant end to food tasting itself.

1) recently, the restaurant has been closed for violations in terms of food safety and cleanliness

2) boss lady. the lady with the mullet and her pictures all over the walls lacks service.my family member was eating at one table and she wanted to move them to another table abruptly asking with no courtesy. 

3) the operation flow is like a restaurant doll house.  when you ask for a number in the front, there is no systems. the front is packed and lacks a line. just horrible experience.

4) cheesy.  the tables are plastered with Mickey Mouse stickers and the front has a trophy mantle case. bad taste.

5) food. a few weeks ago, I ate steamed spare ribs for dim sum.  The pork was just simply rotten and I had to exchange it. I spit it out and luckily avoided food poisoning.

__

So Yelpers just being an active member and giving you guys a warning.
Avoid this place.

  I usually dine at Koi Palace which is more pricier but heck, dim sum after all is meant to be an experience of chatter, banter, good food, service, and great tea.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
COCKROACHES! count em' 1, 2, 3, 4, 5......

Just running on the walls behind us. There were 2 at first, so they call a person over to smash them. Minutes later, 3 more appear from this little hole. 

The worst part weren't the pests, but there was no apology or anything about them! RUDE and DISGUSTING! No wonder there was no wait on a Saturday afternoon.
author: kim w.

description:
Everything was pretty good.

A decent Chinese restaurant with good Dim Sum.  

I'd definitely stop by again if i was in the area.
author: Steven F.

description: The waitress who is tall and wearing glasses was having really bad attitude. She was not put down the food but more like threw the dim sum on the table. The sound of throwing the dim sum was awful. And she forgot to give the soy sauce to the dim sum, I had to ask other waiter to give me the soy sauce. The waiters were great, food is great but only this waitress made me had a bad day there.
author: Vincent C.

description:
After a hard night of partying, you always crave that "I'm going to regret this later" grease. What better than some DIM SUM?!

Visiting my friends in SF, I really wanted to give the SF dim sum a try. We just decided to look up the closest place to where we were staying (walking distance). 

When we first walked in, it's a pretty authentic Chinese restaurant with the decoration and the waitress uniforms. We were seated at what looked like a children's table, with Hello Kitty stickers everywhere on the table. I personally didn't care though as long as the food was good.

Most dim sum places that I've been to have carts that are wheeled around and you just pick whichever one you want. Here however, they give you a list and you write down how many of that you want. I think this could be unbenefical for us later because we can't actually choose which plate we want. 

All the shumai were delicious. I was pretty disappointed with the duck however because there was literally only 2-3 pieces with actual meat on it. The rest was pretty much just skin and bones. Also, we ordered some vegetables and they forgot about it. 

Service was fine, they would check on us regularly but over all experience was tolerable for a rush dim sum craving.
author: Kimmy Y.

description:
I used to frequent S&T for dim sum and never had any complaints. 

The dining space is a reasonable size, but be prepared to wait in line especially on weekends.

They have a limited selection of dim sum, but what they do have is delicious.

Parking is super easy, plenty of street parking in the area.

Pricing is super reasonable.

Probably one of my favorite spots for affordable dim sum in the city.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Okay, this is the first dim sum experience for me.

Dim sum( hearts desire)
A Chinese brunch experience. Basically a buffet that comes to you and you could choose from a list as well. 

This list has many delicious favorites:
Shrimp dumplings, meat dumplings, pork buns, sesame balls, shrimp puffs, taro cakes, turnip dumplings...and it gets better and better. 

This spot was amazing. We experienced delicious sensations with free presentation. 

However minuses are still there 

Service was slow and the customer engagement was little. However that won stop me from coming. 

Thanks Jenny for such an amazing time at s and t
author: Monty P.

description:
Authentic Cantonese dim-sum / seafood restaurant. 

I stumbled in here without reading their reviews. I was in the area getting my SMOG test (76 sunset gas stn which is a great place by the way) and I'm glad I decided to check it out! :)

Heres my scores for S&T:
Pork porridge w/ 1k egg - 8.5/10
Shrimp 'hargaw' - 10! (skin is of good texture/thickness, shrimp is fresh and generous and DE-POOPED)
Maylay egg custard cake 'ma-la-guen' - 9/10
Shrimp noodle roll - 7/10 (nam-wa in ny china town is better)
Shiu Mai 7.5/10 (texture is too soft)
Saltegg custard bun 10

I'm loving' it.
author: Cheung L.

description: As someone from Hong Kong, I am always seeking the food I had from childhood, mostly cantonese food. This place is so far the best I have had in SF area. I went with relative form Hong Kong who live in outer sunset. We had a set menu for $189 which easily fed 8 people. HK style steamed fish was perfectly cooked. Ginger and scallion fried crab was smaller but tasty. A stand out was the dried scallop soup which I am a big fan. It's kind of acquired taste though.
author: Paul I.

description:
As far as Chinese food places go, this ranks right up there with my favorites.

In SF where there's Chinese food on every corner, you really have to make your case as to why one place is better than the one just down the street.

As far as this place goes, it's slightly more expensive than your average Chinese joint, but you definitely get some value out of the added expense. The squid here is prepared perfectly... tender and flavorful, not bland and rubbery like other places. Also, there seems to be a little more refinement as far as the preparation and presentation go.

I highly recommend this place.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
This place is just.. an average Chinese restaurant. Nothing the great, but not terrible.

I tried their soy sauce chicken which they're supposedly known for. Although it was tender (although in a slightly odd way), the bones inside were still bloody, making me a bit uneasy in consuming it. Plus, there wasn't much flavor in the chicken either.

We also had their walnut prawns, salt and pepper short ribs, eggplant and fish, fried rice, soup and dou miao. I could go into a detailed review for each dish, but I'll just cut it short and say that the food is pretty typical Americanized Chinese food, filled with oil and corn starch. It doesn't taste bad, but it's not for the refined palate.
author: Elaine L.

description:
I had chicken with crispy noodles. I don't think crispy noodles are something people order a lot from this restaurant. I was craving crispy noodles, I was in the area and it was on the menu, so gave it a shot.  The crispy noodles themselves were good, the sauce was perfect. The chicken was a little odd (soft and too white in color) but tasty. But I can't complain since it is clear that seafood and dim sum is their specialty.

The place was clean and the staff was attentive and efficient. The overall decor was little kitschy but not off-putting. I wish I could add a photo but unfortunately my phone went dead. 
I'm not sure I would return here but if I found myself in that neighborhood again?  possibly.
author: Gary B.

description:
Hmm.....I'd have to agree with everyone else in that this place only deserves 3.5 stars.  

First, we walked in before 10am and the place was closed.  Dim sum should be served early in the morning!!!!! Not after 10am!!!!

Second, I sit down at a table and there is a small bug walking around on it. Yuck.

Third,  the dining area smells like a mix of sour and saltiness.  Thats the best I can do to describe the weird smell here. 

Fourth, their chairs and tables are stained and/or peeling too.

On the plus side, the food was good. It was tasty and clean because I didnt have a stomach ache. Plus their bathroom is extremely clean! (I always worry about dirty bathrooms at asian restaurants).  The bill between two people was pretty reasonable, approximately $20 for about 7 dishes.
author: Janet E.

description:
Had a feast with the fam here...  Everything was pretty darn good.  I was pretty impressed that the quality of each dish shined through.  Had the dungeness crab encrusted with salted duck egg yolk (Yummy), salt and pepper pork (tasty), snow pea leaves with garlic (fresh), letttuce wraps (refreshing), soy sauce chicken (tender), Steamed striped bass (fresh), chicken and salted fish fried rice (loved it).  Ended it off with their complimentary red bean soup (ok).

I must say that I wasn't expecting too much, and was pleasantly surprised from our experience.

Heard some good things about their newer sister restaurant in San Mateo - H.K. Causeway Bay.  Could be worth trying out their Dim Sum!
author: Lawrence L.

description:
There are really good dim sum places, then there are places like Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant. The dim sum is average for some things and better for others, but you come here anyway because the location makes it the most convenient place to visit. I did have a few firsts when I visited this time.

I tried pan-fried duck chin with maggi sauce for the first time. There isn't much meat on a duck chin as one might imagine, but the flavors were good. I felt like a dog chewing on a bone for the longest time just trying to extract any meat left on the bone, only to be disappointed. It makes me wonder how they procured so many duck chins to cook. The other first I tried today was the baked durian turnover. I've heard people who either love or hate this fruit. Andrew Zimmern has tried multiple times to eat this fruit only to be disgusted by the smell and texture. I braved up and tried a bite and decided it wasn't so bad. In fact, the taste was sweet and reminded me of pumpkin flavored cream cheese - I actually kind of liked it. It helped that it was baked into a flakey pastry. 

Some other highlights from dim sum was the lobster noodles, which had a ton of ginger and garlic. I also enjoyed the fried tofu and the deep fried balls filled with pork. Major disappointments included the super dry and soup-less xiao long baos and the mushy BBQ pork turnovers.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Besides the other Chinese Restaurants that, I have been to like on Irving, Balboa, Clement, Geary, San Francisco Chinatown. 

S&T Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant is not that bad of a place. I have been here for lunch and dinner several times. The food here is wonderful.The food items that, I like would be the Sweet And Sour Pork Chops, Honey Glazed Walnuts With Shrimp With Mayo, Crispy Chicken With Shrimp Chips, Peking Duck With Steamed Bun.
author: William B.

description:
I loveeeee this place. I went yesterday for lunch. It was dimsum and good. i've had better xlb's, but the duck here is good, the zha leong (?) my canto sucks, it's like you tiao wrapped in chang fun for those who know what i'm taling about, is delicious, I also had the pumpkin with salted egg yolk. this is a must!
it's basically pumpkin fries in salted egg yolk batter and fried. IT DOESNT TASTE GOOD THE NEXT DAY SO BE SURE TO FINISH ALL THEM PUMPKIN FRIES. 
 the chicken feet in abalone sauce was really good too! these were kind of my highlights, if I think of what else I ordered I'll revise this post. 

And the food looks so pretty and elegant. I forgot my phone at work the previous night and so I couldnt take pics or else I would have uploaded a buncho pics. I'll go again just to take pics and upload them here. 

dimsum is always pretty cheap, and it's best to get dimsum when you have a big party so you can order/sample more stuff.
author: Emily K.

description:
The bomb!!! I got a rec from a friend who grew up in the area and has some authority on authenticity. She told me to "skip Chinatown because it is overpriced and low quality" and head out to Sunset. I followed here advice a few years ago and was very pleasantly surprised. Came back with the wifey last week and was again impressed. We ordered a lot so strap on your seat belts. 

We ordered the Har Gow (about $3 I think), Spinach and shrimp dumpling (about $3), BBQ Pork Bun (about $3), Roast Duck ($5), Fried Calamari ($5), Fried Chicken Wings ($5), and the Singapore Noodles ($11). You are probably asking yourself, "Was all of that really necessary?" Well the waiter was asking the same thing. We didn't finish it, but I am sure that it made for some really tasty left-overs for this one homeless man back in the Mission. 

Anyhow, The Har Gow were amazing. Perfectly flavored and so delish. The spinach and shrimp dumplings were really good too, but not quite as good as the Har Gow. The BBQ pork buns were the best I have ever had. It was not that cheesy looking died-red meat, but was very tender and flavorful, nice sized chunks of pork. There was a great meat-bun ratio and the bun was really good. The wifey loved it, which says a lot because she does not care for these typically. in fact, i have never seen her eat one before. 

The roast duck was probably the best, if not definitely in the top three, that I have ever had (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TR5FbzexqkO0jJ7Sc3MsMA?select=WdpmXuCeUTBLG-qaHsI6uA). i had some good duck in Singapore and in Malaysia chinatowns, but this was cooked with care. The skin was very crispy, the meat was perfectly seasoned, and it was cooked perfectly. A+! The chicken wings were one of the few things that we though we could have lived without. They weren't bad by any means, but they just weren't amazing. They were basic salt and pepper fried chicken wings. The calamari was quite exceptional though. Perfectly seasoned and battered and cooked to a perfect tenderness. No chewiness, which is amazing. I questioned whether or not it was really calamari. 

The Singapore noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TR5FbzexqkO0jJ7Sc3MsMA?select=_Kz5XRhmIkJBcj23vVEUiQ)were very aptly named. Very thin rice noodles pan fried with curry powder, char siu pork, shrimp, and egg. They were so flavorful and delicious and really showed a nice mix of Indian/Indonesian, Chinese, and native Malay seasoning. It brought me back to the place for sure. 

The chili sauce that they served was phenomenal. Hands down, the best Asian Chili sauce i have ever tasted. It was so deep, layered and flavorful, I could have just eaten that with some wonton chips and been happy. The mustard was really good too, cleared the sinuses right out. 

I do not know the Chinese names for the things that we ordered, but I bet you everyone else in the restaurant did. We were the only non-Asians and, it seemed, the only folks that did not speak Chinese. Experiences like that are some of my favorite aspects of America. I hope places like this continue to thrive and welcome foreigners. All of the staff were extremely friendly, welcoming, and helpful. The service was quick, but they also were not too busy. Definitely make the trip out to check it out. It is so worth it!
author: Miguel V.

description:
S&T Hong Kong Seafood is hands down the highest quality Chinese Restaurant in the Sunset District.  Located on Noriega and 30th near a slew of competition, this place is by far the best.  The service is fast, top quality, friendly, sincere, and memorable.  Simon, the waiter who took care of us talk about interesting culinary details of the dish.

For $80, you can purchase a five course dinner for 4.  With that order was an amazing shark fin soup, a vegetable and beef order that was excellent, a whole steamed fish seasone with green onions and ginger that was hearty, a vegetable dish, and there was one other dish that was quite good.  The atmosphere is classic Hong Kong style and reminiscent of many restaurants I frequented when I visited Hong Kong many years ago.  Classic bright lights, fast pace, yet very professional service.

The wine was superb and my friends and I had an excellent time.  One interesting detail was a newspaper review from the Chronicle which indicated that S&T was the best Chinese Restaurant in San Francisco.  The restaurant critics from the SF Chronicle are known to be very picky.    If you have been here in the past and have not enjoyed the experience, the management has changed many times, but, over the past 10 years, it's been under the same ownership.  I met the owner, a woman who was very sincere and had the energy of a person who abides by high standards.

The waiter who took care of our table, a very friendly man, was a sincere host who gave us an excellent complimentary green bean soup for dessert at the end.  

The wine, the food, the service, and overall "time" was an enjoyable experience.  I cannot wait to come here again.  Even on a slow weekday late at night, the place was crowded and filled with life.
author: Tony U.

description: I give this place 2 stars. Very small portions and expensive. Not appetizing either. I came here with my boyfriend. Note: If you're not Asian, don't eat here. Everyone in that restaurant kept staring at us. Very rude and uncomfortable experience
author: Glacier M.

description: one of the best dimsum place u can find in SF, service might not be the best sometimes.
author: Zack Y.

description:
I don't understand why so many Chinese places have names like this. S&T, D&A, ABC.. huh? Anywho... 

Woke up WAY too early but I was bribed by family to get out of bed for dim sum. Glad I did!  We were seated promptly at 9am by some man in a gray vest. Reminds me of all dim sum restaurants and their outfits. They always wear vests which I find kind of cute. Dressing up for breakfast! Place filled up fast so don't drag your feet if you want a seat here.

It's more expensive than the average dim sum restaurant but they sure give you your moneys worth.  It's the subtle things that make a restaurant earn extra brownie points. I knew it was going to be a good meal when I noticed they added cilantro in the bbq pork rice roll, which is just a little something more than usual.

Also loved the bean curd roll.  It was filled with pork and shreds of vegetables that combined all the flavors so nicely. The Chicken and Rice in Lotus Leaf has always been a favorite of mine.  Lovin' the egg yolk and Chinese sausage they added in.  It's like a little surprise when you dig through the rice :) I don't normally order egg rolls but they make them extra crunchy and when you dip it in the spicy red sauce your mouth just waters! Their beef chow fun wasn't greasy at all and I happily finished my meal off with a Egg Custard Tart.  Skip the Shanghai Dumplings here though.. save that order for Shanghai Dumpling King in the Richmond district.

Oh. And something unfortunate happened during our meal.

My mother: *facing the window* Omg. They're going to take the trash in through the front..
Me: ewwwww
Mother: Really.
Me: Eeeewww! *Turns around*

Isn't it a health code violation to drag the trash can THROUGH the restaurant?! I wasn't thrilled to see some smelly can dragging next to all the food and people. Even so, food was great and I'll forgive them if they never drag another trash can through the restaurant while I'm there again.........Ignorance is bliss.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I went there with my mom on a weekday and we were seated immediately. I scanned the list of dim sum items to order and yes, it is a bit pricey.

We ordered the basics; pork sui mai, shrimp dumplings, baked bbq pork buns, the egg custard steam bun and an order of Chicken, Gui Long (Chinese broccoli) chow mien. The food was great - the pork sui mai was larger than at other dim sum restaurants, the egg custard bun was my favorite and it was delicious. 

Overall, the food is great, but more expensive than at other Dim Sum restaurants. I'm curious to see the wait time during a busy weekend lunch. I'm glad I tried it and I was pleased with the food, but I would probably come here as a treat or for special occasions.
author: Allie L.

description: My experience in this restaurant is awful! The food was great!! I would give 4 stars for the food, but the customer service was terrible. The waiters were nice, but there was one waitress really pissed me off. When she served me food, she just threw the dim sum on the table. She was showing a very bad attitude. And then she left without saying a word!! I will never come back here again!
author: Sharon H.

description:
No rubber food here! The squid and scallops were tender and perfectly cooked. The was soy sauce chicken moist and delectable. Every dish was excellent! A kitchen that cares about the food... wow! And on top of that... great service! Not just from one waiter, but the entire staff! 

Way to make us feel welcome and leave us well fed and happy!

This is DEFINITELY one of our go-to places for family dinner.

Oh and one more thing. They charge tip for large parties, but make it very clear in English as well as Chinese, the tip charge. I like that!

(note: no AmEx, but Visa/MC ok...learned by experience lol)
author: Kenneth T.

description:
Dim sum review only:

the dim sum here is actually really good. It used to be worse but it's been under new management for a while and the last few times I've been, the food has been good. Always start out with some jasmine tea, just because. Then it's onto the entrees:

Shrimp dumplings: They always have them fresh and piping hot, and the skin doesn't just fall off the shrimp when you try to pick it up, like at other places. One of my favs.

Pork Siu Mai: You can get it with or without the shrimp but so many other dishes have shrimp, it's better to get it just regular. Plump and juicy pork in every bite.

Chicken feet with black bean sauce: Maybe it's a Chinese thing but why WASTE a part of an animal...jeez! The sauce makes it really good, just imagine you're spitting out like fish bones or something...

And whatever else satisfies your craving. Also we haven't ordered it the past few times but I do remember they used to have some cheap ass lobster chow-fun during dim sum time.
author: Wilson T.

description:
02.27.11

Dim sum with mom and pop.

No dim sum cart ladies.  They will occasionally bring dishes out on a platter.  You do your ordering on a menu.  It's pretty high tech for a Chinese restaurant.

Almost everything we ordered were excellent.  Go for the siu mai, hai cheung, and the soy sauce noodles.

Skip: green onion pancakes, even though they're only $1.99.

Will be back!
author: Jenny L.

description: Good dim sum. Lines can be long. Mediocre service.
author: Yelp R.

description:
0 Star


A bitchy owner just yelled and cursed before rudely asking us to leave her restaurant.
This was because we sent a fried fish back to a kitchen due to its bad smelling.

She loudly said in Chinese translated to "This is a frozen fish. If you guys do not like the smell, never ever come back to my restaurant." 

It was so serious that we were about to call a police. However, we were nice enough to pay for what we ate before we left.

Anyway, we are going to report the Health Department. Most importantly, we wanna tell her to do something else if she hates to service people. Servers were nice to us though.


If you want to eat a real frozen seafood with unexpected services. 
Try this HELL Kitchen.....
author: Ari C.

description:
Big family reunion (15 of us!) at S&T Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant, we were packed like sardines at the table, but we had a ton of fun.  We ordered the traditional chinese banquet dinner and it was pretty good...Not Koi Palace or R&G good, but still quite respectable, probably the top pick for traditional Chinese dinner if you live in Outer/Inner Sunset.

Check out my snapshots, they speak for themselves.

I heart family!
author: Burrito M.

description:
My family opened the Lunar New Year by having dinner at S&T. I don't think I've had this kind of quality Chinese food in a long time. We didn't order anything exquisite because we're not made out of money and that's just it. Average people food that taste excellent is just what people need more of these days. 

We ordered a Crab Meat and Fish Maw Soup, House Special Chicken (aka Empress Chicken), Salt and Pepper Spareribs, Fish and Tofu Claypot, and a Lotus Root and Baby Fish Stir-fry. You get what you ask for. They do not skimp on any of the ingredients and it was strictly no frills, solid, good food. 

The crab meat in the soup tasted fresh and sweet; the chicken meat was tender and springy; the spareribs were lightly battered and salted perfectly; the claypot had literally only fish and tofu but it was full of what Chinese people call "breath of a wok" meaning it was piping hot; and the stir-fry was interesting but very delicious. 

S&T is a little bit more expensive than other restaurants but you get what you pay for. For an extra couple of bucks for each dish, I don't mind eating some quality food. I know everyone in the packed restaurant that night probably agreed with me too.
author: Diana C.

description: Food is ok typical.  Customer service is nothing to really write about because of the people are very inconsistent.  Soy Chicken or Tea Chicken is tender and juicy but quality has changed.
author: Philip W.

description: Above standard Chinese fare. Prices are very reasonable. Food is fresh and well prepared. Place is a little dated, services is like any normal busy restaurant. Dim sum is good. The only negative is that the owner is always skulking around with a scowl on her face. If she gets to know you she can be quite nice, but if she does not recognize you, beware.
author: K M.

description:
So I came in here with a friend on New Year's day to fill my stomach up since I threw everything up the night before. I was pleasantly surprised. 

Got in here at about 10:30, didn't have to wait for a table, and ordered some of my usual dim sum favorites. Cha siu sow, Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce, ha gow, siu mai, etc. We also ordered pei dan jook, which was great for the first hangover for the year, though it did come out a little too salty for my taste.

One of the things that sets this dim sum restaurant apart is it's take out window. Sandwiched behind a paper screen and what would be the fire exit are a couple of glass cases with a few additional dishes you can order without even stepping in. I didn't see any of the waitresses carting those dishes around. Something to ask about the next time I come back.
author: Tony L.

description:
Had my grandfather's 80th birthday party here with about 50 people who came. This place was really popular because they had at least 3 other parties going on that night at the same time. Worked with Teresa to hammer out a menu. 11 courses and in some cases, tables with kids, 12 courses all for around $271 a table. She was really friendly and helpful, even gave us her cell number in case we had any extra questions. The food was delicious and everyone left completely filled. At the end of dinner she gave us steamed peach buns, they were the BEST buns i've ever had.
I will def tell everyone to come here for their parties, extremely helpful and friendly, she gave us our own half of the restaurant from 5pm till closing and even let me in early to set up everything I needed to. She places special red table cloths on all the tables and even did seat covers for the head table!
author: Brian J.

description: Good dim sum, but not anything special. A big drawback for me is that they don't have carts zipping around and everything has to be ordered from a checklist. Standard dim sum fare, but their soup dumpling was pretty tasty. For one order, you get a mini-tureen of two loosely-wrapped dumplings and a chunk of shark fin (I know, no Pee Cee). Very rich  chicken broth and a dash of vinegar goes well with it! I also liked their pig liver sashimi. Really thinly-sliced pieces of liver steamed on top of bean sprouts with an oil and soy dipping sauce. Surprisingly tasty umami bombs.
author: Kevin L.

description: Well my sister Serra N. was more generous on her review of this place than me... Yes, the service was wonderul and the dim sum was "good."  The mark down comes from them charging us $1 each for tea... when only 2 out of 6 of us drank any.  They didn't even ask if we wanted it.  Like my 4 year old niece was drinking tea even if my sister said it was OK? NOOOOO.  I eat dim sum at every opportunity and theirs was good not great... and to really top it off... it was pricier than I have ever paid anywhere............ go figure...
author: Lydia K.

description:
Whenever I have a day off and have lunch plans with my mom, this seems to be our default place. This has also been a default place for dinner when we can't decide where to eat at. I've been less than impressed the last couple times I have been here. 

If you do make reservations for dinner, be sure you get there on time or else your table will be swooped by another family who doesn't understand that reservations come before those who don't have reservations. Food is alright and I must say really expensive. I guess it's probably the fact that the place looks nice and doesn't look like a hole in the wall-- but honestly you can have some really good (and cheaper) food at a hole in the wall and be treated much better than the workers here.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
We went here for some dim sum and thought the dishes served were pretty good - not amazing, but for the price, its a great value. They have some off menu items that my host knew about (some kind of dumpling in soup) with shark fins... 

Mmmm, food always taste better if you know that they are becoming endangered...On the wall, you can see photoshopped images of the owner with various taiwanese, HK singers and stars which make for great conversation. As per most chinese places, service is served with no smile and a little bit of attitude.
author: B H.

description:
I have been coming here for years. My family usually comes here for dinner, but this time, we got dim sum. We got cha sui chong fun, sesame ball, woo gok, hahm suey gock, custard tart, and portugese tart. Dim sum is pretty good here. 

Dinner is better. We ususally get the sizzling beef, honey walnut prawns, mo po tofu, curry crab, chicken, sometimes duck, and spareribs. 

Everything is pretty good here. Service is ok, however sometimes they serve rice at the end of the meal which doesn't make sense. OVerall solid place to come.
author: tracey l.

description: So Fantastic you need to keep this place a secret. Complex, mind blowing flavors entice you out of your comfort zone to an adventure of exquisite food.
author: P. H.

description:
I've lived in the sunset for a good chunk of my life and have recently rediscovered this restaurant. While most people come here for dim sum (which is pretty good), I'm going to write my review about dinner.

As others have said, a MUST HAVE is their Soy Sauce Chicken. While it is a bit pricey at $10.85 for half a chicken, the quality more than makes up for it. The meat is tender, smooth, and flavorful. They also give you their own soy dipping sauce (not plain soy sauce) which only enhances the dish.

For soups I would recommend their Crab Meat with Fish Maw soup. Now this is on the more Chinese end of soups (compared to the way Americanized Egg Drop Soup). For a decent price, you get an abundant amount of Crab and Fish Maw in a nice hot clear soup.

Everything else on their vast menu is at the very least decent, but I have yet to try too many of the dishes. So far I haven't come across anything that I absolutely didn't like. I would've given them 5 stars, but they lost 1 because they are a bit pricey for a Chinese Restaurant.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Yummers! I just had dinner tonight and the 9 course meal was pretty good for the money. Large portions too. I really like the shark fin soup they made, it was smooth and the soup was flavored just right *no need to add soy sauce!*. Yes, I know they're banned, but this was my last hurrah in that delicacy...and thanks to this place, it was memorable.
I thought the honey walnut prawns were okay (more mayonnaise flavor than most places, and the fried mini strings on the nuts were too hard to chew), the abalone mushroom with baby bok choy was also a hit at my table, and the fish was moist and flaky. The bowls of noodles had a good chicken base flavor and the texture was perfect.  My favorite dish was the stir fried garlic lobsters...OMG, they were awesome with lots of ginger and garlic clinging to every morsel.
My parents really like the dessert which consisted of freshly made peach buns with yellow mung beans inside, and the green bean sweet soup which wasn't that sweet...so it was perfect for the diabetic seniors at our table.

Service was brisk and they changed our plates quite often. Parking is metered along the street so you have to make sure to grab what you can, when you can.
author: Pauline L.

description:
We had dim sum here yesterday. The first thing we noticed was that the chair height was too low. We had to stand up to get food because the table was too high and there was no lazy susan. The best dish there was the steamed custard bun. The custard was nice and smooth and not to sweet. The shrimp and mushroom crepes were good, but the hahm sui gook and egg rolls were under fried. The prices were higher than most places. 

As most people mentioned, the service was terrible. The waiters and the owner were running around like chickens with their head cut off with nothing getting done. We waited for them to take our order for awhile and for the food to come out. They should maybe have more people in the kitchen helping to get the food out than all the distracting waiters shouting to each other across the room. 

We will stick with the Grand Palace in SSF. There's plenty of parking, a variety of food comes out fast on carts, and there is comfortable seating.
author: Anna K.

description:
Ok this place got so much better. I think they read my review ahaha jkjk probably don't care even if they read it.

Ok last time i came here, no one cared about what I wanted, this time they actually do care now. Because they want TIPS. If you don't give 10% or more.. they will follow you out and ask how come we did not get over 10% TIP ATLEAST!!! True story. 
 
On to the food now, I only come here for DIM SUM, By far the best place i've tried on noriega. Been here a couple of times now, but i still believe they can do better. 

Keep up the good work and improve more and more
author: Andrew H.

description:
We have dined at the S&T Hong Kong Seafood Inc. Restaurant in the Sunset more than a dozen times in recent years, and found the food delicious each time. Regardless of what course we order, we have never been disappointed (except for the steamed fish on Oct 7). I would give 5-star for the cuisine and the presentation. For the quality and portion, the price is reasonable.

The waiters are nice and helpful. They have a sense of humor, too. I give them 4-star for their service.

However, our experience with the owner, a short-hair woman, turned out to be most unpleasant. And I wish to give a negative star for our experience. Our dinner reservation was at 7 pm.  Our friends arrived at the restaurant before 7 pm. We showed up around 7:05 p.m. We waited around for a while, and assumed our name would be called when our table was ready.

Since no one came to our group to let us know how much longer we would have to wait, my husband checked with the woman owner if our table would be ready soon. She snapped and shouted "this is the THIRD time you (guys) have asked!!!"  My husband was caught by surprise by such rude behavior and said "this is my first time checking on our reservation." The woman owner kept the same tone and demeanor "Your table is being cleaned right now!!!"

When our food was served, I asked the waiter why the woman owner would treat her customer(s) with such bad attitude. He explained that's how customers would remember her. I then commented it would be awful to work for someone like her. The waiter's response was "we have learned to ignore her."

Frankly, I do not understand how one can stay in business if the owner can treat her customers in such way.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This place is close to my parent's house in Sunset.  I love coming for for Dim Sum and dinner.  

The food is very authentic.  One of my favorite dish is Crab with Salty egg deep fried ($22.95).  A must try if you like crab.  Shark fin soup, beef pan fried noodles, green mustard with garlic, deep fried tofu with shrimp, dried scallop soup, peking duck with buns are also really good.  

I had my Mother's 70th birthday here December of last year.  Everything was wonderful.  We reserved 5 tables and all the food was excellent.  Hardly anything left on the table to take home.  The banquet menu with tax and tip come to $1350.00, which was a great deal.  

The service is descent. Parking can be challenging depending on time of the day you come here.
author: Rose F.

description: I enjoy coming here for dim sum with my family. The dim sum always comes up piping hot and is very fresh. I appreciate that unlike many dim sum establishments in the sunset, they use fresh ingredients and the quality is high- expect distinguishable ingredients in all their dumplings PLUS nice, thin wrappers. Service is good, but not the best. Bathrooms are clean.
author: Carmen L.

description:
I've come here quite a few times with my parents this year; they seem to favor this place for the convenient location to my apartment, the service, and the food. So I'll simply summarize my own thoughts from my multiple visits here:

1) Dim Sum - Can be a little slow in bringing them out, but the food has been satisfying; I like the plates of vegetables we can order with regular dim sum dishes, e.g., shu mai, pork buns, etc. Sometimes the food can be a little greasy though.

2) Lunch/Dinner - Love the fish here, and the various meat/vegetable dishes are also satisfying. Big family-sized portions; definitely meant for groups.

Service has been varied, but the servers are generally polite with requests from my father. Once, a waiter gave us a hard time for not finishing one of the specialty dishes...but of course he was just picking on us in jest. We just laughed along with him.

The clientele of this place is heavily Chinese, but they talk with us in both Cantonese and English depending on the server.
author: Helene K.

description: Do not come here. After being one the first to be seated, waited 45 minutes to get our food. At a dim sum restaurant u would expect to see carts. No carts at all! Order by menu. Check out other restaurants before.comimg here.
author: David S.

description:
Cheap dim sum, service is typical (as in grunts), and their food is okay for the prices.  

I love their rice noodle rolls with XO sauce!  I'll admit though that some of their dishes are too greasy, and they have dim sum, via pre-ordering.   

Parking is an utter pain...but you need to look harder.  

I come here, if I am too lazy to drive to the other side of the park for better dim sum.
author: Fannie S.

description: They serve delectable dim sum hot and fast, so we weren't waiting too long in between dishes. I particularly liked the shrimp dim sums, such as the deep fried shrimp balls, pan fried shrimp & chive dumpling, and shrimp dumpling (hargaw). I didn't really care for the donut with rice noodle roll and the BBQ pork noodle roll because the donut and pork didn't taste fresh.
author: Cliff W.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday dinner last weekend.  The signage out front threw me off since I was scouring Noriega for "S & T", and apparently this restaurant is known by everyone on earth as "Hong Kong Seafood".   Oops.

We chose one of the many set dinner options for ten, which came out to about $24 pp.  Feasted on what felt like a ten course wedding banquet, which included cold appetizer plate, sharks fin soup, walnut prawns, veggies, salted egg crab, steamed fish, etc. etc.  Your typical Cantonese style seafood, but done well.  And a ton of food for the price.

Service was surprisingly good with the wait staff being on top of service, cracking jokes with us, and cutting up and serving the birthday cake without qualms.
author: Joanne G.

description: This place is alright. It's no Hong Kong, but it's better than some of the other dim sum places in the Sunset/Richmond district. Decent variety and reasonable prices.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I came here for a family dinner on a Sunday evening, waited for about 10 minutes before seated.  The last time I came was 10 years ago, I heard they are under new management and lots have changed.  

We ordered the half soy sauce and white chicken.  The soy sauce chicken was excellent; white chicken was just okay.  The black pepper short rib was delicious.  We also had the crab meat and fish maw soup, it was really good as well.  The only thing I didn't like about it was the food was very greasy, but I guess that's what makes it good.  The price is a little more expensive than other casual Chinese places, but quality makes up for it.  I will come back someday.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Meh. Cheap dim sum, comes to around $10 pp with tip, but the service was hideous. Absolutely rude. The food was fine. If the service was just normal, I would have given more stars. 

We ordered shrimp fried rice which was tasteless.

Our tea was empty, and the top was opened. No one cared. We had empty dim sum plates, and they just put down more food without removing the plates. Surprisingly, they were packed on a Tuesday afternoon. I will not return.
author: Goshen F.

description:
Hungover, sleepy, and not wearing a bra. That's me on Sunday morning when my roommate's boyfriend dragged me out of bed b/c he was stood up at the cliff house. 

I managed to brush my teeth and find the ray-bans and was kidnapped to this place. I should note that it was bay to breakers day and I was NOT IN THE MOOD TO DEAL WITH TRAFFIC so my rules of sunset only were abided by. *sort of*

After waiting for close to an hour for a table and running into several relatives of my dining companion, we were seated. The thought of anything other than coffee made me less than enthusiastically mark a "1" next to the Shanghai dumplings. However, my companion ordered EVERYTHING and a tsing tao. 

Not knowing my bullshit detector, he but some meat on my plate and said it was "beef". I'm f'ing hispanic which means I know for damn sure what tripe is... oh well.

After the third Tsing Tao, I had eaten the blood jello, frog, chicken feet, tripe, pork ribs, duck, shark fin, and lobster... a whole menagerie of animals if you will. Sometimes I just wish that eating with the chinese anthony bourdain could've waited until after four. Beggars can't be choosers, I guess. 

P.S.-- our bill came to well over $200 but that's just b/c we kept buying startled elderly diners tsing taos in an effort to liven up the joint. i heard myself referred to as "crazy white girl" which to me is a compliment and well worth the check.
author: dr S.

description:
I drove by this place plenty of times thinking it wasn't really good but just a place to go to...surprisingly i found parking on a SUNDAY! i guess i went early enough..

this place is pretty packed...really hungry older Asian people who are willing to cut you in line to say that they are first (I'm Asian so i can make fun of ourselves)...

this place no all that eye catching...the seats had duct tape on it and looked almost run down..but the food is amazing!

you can order off the piece of paper and its easy to read...for all you non-chinese reading people (including me)....the best was the fried chinese donut with the noodles wrapped around it...i also liked the tripe and shrimp and beef noodle...it was pretty good! i must come here again..but if someone cuts me off..im gonna go crazy!
author: Brendan L.

description: The food is decent enough to garner local support from the Chinese community for a cheap to moderately priced menu. The dim sum is good for the price you pay, but don't expect anything fine or special. I would give this place a 3 stars rating in comparison to Chinese restaurants of its class (local family eatery). The one star is for the dining experience because the waiting staff was really rude on the day of my visit to the point of being hostile. I went in for a no frills dim sum lunch and was delighted to see that they had Vietnamese style egg rolls on the menu and ordered it with great anticipation because I just happen to have a craving for Vietnamese imperial rolls. What came out was regular Chinese cabbage egg rolls. When I asked a waiter what it was, he admitted that they were Chinese vegetarian egg rolls and they didn't have Vietnamese egg rolls. So I wondered why they would attempt to serve me something I didn't order without first informing me and this led the waiter to talk to his manager before he agreed to take the dish back without charge (luckily I had not eaten any of the egg rolls, because it was obvious they were not Vietnamese style egg rolls and I thought a simple mistake may have been made). As I was leaving after finishing lunch, another waiter stopped me (literally blocked my way out) and told me in my face (really loudly) that no one should expect a Cantonese seafood restaurant to actually serve Vietnamese egg rolls even if it's on the menu, just like no one should expect to find authentic Shanghai dumplings in a Cantonese restaurant. He warned for me to even harbor such an expectation was a serious mistake and I should not do that again. Of course this was total nonsense. The restaurant not only misrepresented itself in writing on the menu but it's the customer's fault for questioning something that wasn't ordered? By that time I just wanted to get out of the place as I was afraid of getting hit. So I apologized for being an idiot and thanked the waiter for his advice and was then let go. Wow! These people need some serious crash course on customer service. And please get the Vietnamese style egg roll off the menu if you don't have it. Oh, BTW, lots of Cantonese restaurants serve great Shanghai dumplings as well as Vietnamese style egg rolls.
author: Giovani T.

description:
Mmm! I bring my nonchinese friends here, it's a good place to intro them to dim sum. One of my friends is addicted now! The prices are higher than other dim sum joints but the quality is great. Large restuarant. Gets crowded on weekends. Eexpect a wait.

get the shrimp dumplings!
author: Veranna N.

description:
Food is hit or miss here. 

Things you should go for.

1.Some sort of Tempura fried with "salty egg".
2.The crispy skinned chicken.
3. Mix mushroom plate
4. Eggplant and fish pot.

Double check your bill, since they overcharged me twice here.
author: Dorian T.

description: Good selection of dim sum but arrive early If having a large party it tends to get busy after 11am on the weekends, dinner was delicious too doesn't taste too oily, would come again.
author: Linh D.

description:
Good Dim Sum. Very clean. Good service.

Almost sounds like a jackpot, isn't it? They have great variety, and they were all very good. Very fresh, and this place is not overly crowded.. so everything came out fast. I heard the owner used to work in Koi Palace which kind of explains the higher standard quality. Plus they have pictured of famous HK actors and actress on the wall, hmmm.... 

Finally found a good dim sum spot around outer Sunset.
author: Marlis T.

description:
I live really close to this place so my parents and I come for dim sum quite often and I had dinner there recently to celebrate my mother's birthday. It's like any typical Chinese restaurant unorganized but the food was still good. I go to places like this not for the service but for the food. The one down fall is the long wait on the weekends. My parents enjoy their dim sum because it's not too salty, which is a change from a lot of other Chinese restaurants.   
Like I said the service is not that great, but during my mother's dinner it was a whole new level of horrible service. My mother asked if what we ordered came with rice and the waiter told me my mom very rudely, "No, of course not what do you think rice is not automatic with the meal". It was in his tone of voice belittling my mother's question, which made me very upset.  
The worse part of it all was, the food wasn't even that good, which is the reason for the mediocre rating. 
The sizzling seafood rice soup we order lacked any sizzle and it tasted more like instant soup with seafood and snap peas. It took them a long time to serve us, which it's normal due to the weather and being I was there for dinner on a Saturday night; however, I was not pleased with the food; the Peking duck we ordered was way too fatty. 
Overall their dim sum is better than their dinner and the service there is not great. The waiter we had was obnoxious and we will probably not choose to go there as often anymore.
author: Diana L.

description: I'm a fan.  Service was actually pretty good contrary to other reviews.  Perhaps its the cantonese.
author: Koalie W.

description:
The price is right and the food is very delicious!!

The servers are okay, but they take cares of elders, try to let them sit down as soon as possible~
author: Vivian F.

description:
They could have gotten a five-star if their prices are better. 
I mean $3 for a dim sum dish? come on... 

Otherwise, this place is good for a dim sum lunch! 
The Peking Duck is delish! 
The veggies are fresh and delicious!
My friend ordered 2 more dishes that I have eaten before but just never got to know the name. 

I feel welcomed here, but there is a stigma that comes with being Asian and not being able to speak Cantonese. Thank god my friend speaks Cantonese or else I would try to communicate with broken English and hand signals. 

That would be fun. lol.
author: Miss C.

description:
Pro: good food for a decent price and they can almost never mess up on your order because they give you a menu to mark up what you want. This way your food comes out nice and hot too.

Con: I almost always get dirty looks from the waiters until I start to speak Cantonese to them. The service is okay... But you can't really expect much.

only come here for the convenience.
author: Jessica T.

description: Beware they charge $1.65 per person for steamed rice. It doesn't sound like a lot but when have a group of 6 or more wait til you see that $10 or more for that covered bowl of steamed rice. What a rip off. Rest of the food was ok. Their soy sauce chicken is alright. expensive place try others for better value or quality for the price
author: Al S.

description: I went her yesterday night for dinner with my family after coming back from The California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park. We came to this restaurant randomly, because we were tired of driving around to find a place to eat. When  we arrived at the restaurant, there were only a few table dining, and we were seated right away as we entered. We took a look at the menu, then we ordered. We ordered in Chinese, a Crab, Spareribs with XO Sauce, Oxtail in Red wine Sauce, and Crispy Chicken. We were asked if we wanted rice and we said yes. The waiters also came by and changed our plates and gave us new ones. The family liked the crab, the Spareribs were okay, not the best I've had. The Chicken I thought was a little dry, and as for the Oxtail it was decent. Overall, I'd give this restaurant a  3 stars.
author: Mystery M.

description:
Gave this place a 2nd try & ate here on a Sunday and still don't think it's worth a line to have dim sum here. the food was not that great where I was still burping the food I have intake till the evening. 
Its the only one out of 2 dim sum restaurants in Sunset, but it's more worth traveling to other district such as Richmond or down South in Daly City or Millbrae areas for dim sum. This place is trying to hot sell it's place with HK celebrities photos taken with the owner of this restaurant, which makes me wonder what was the criteria determined to be a good restaurant for them to consider coming here.
I really don't think the celebrities who took photos with the owner would've came all the way out to Sunset to eat there, I'm sure it's at a different location in San Mateo perhaps to attract more Asian customers in the area.
The ladies who were dropping off my order also has an attitude... Its worse than going to Chinatown for dim sum.
author: M W.

description:
This place was SOOOO good! I recommend going with Cantonese-speaking friends that know their dim sum. We were seated relatively quickly (maybe a 5 minute wait) even though there seemed to be a lot of people and the restaurant is quite small. This restaurant had a great variety of dim sum, more than any other I've been to in the Bay Area (which, granted, isn't that many). I tried a lot of new things and I was really stuffed by the end. We even had to take 2 boxes home. For 5 people, came out to be about $15 per person including tax and tip.

I was really happy with this restaurant despite there being only one restroom and women are soooooooooo slow when using the restroom. 

I would definitely go here again!! (we parked on the street)
author: Esther Y.

description: The waiters/waitresses have always been kind.  I believe this is a higher end Asian restaurant.  It isn't as rude as other places! HAHA.
author: Tina L.

description:
Christmas Eve morning and kids say "we want dim sum".  Mom is at the gym so we roll over to South Sea Village.  What....closed.  I mean it's 10 'clock am.  What gives.  Ah, Friday.  OK Plan B.  Call over to S & T and they say of course we're open.  We roll.  Place is pretty full at 10:15, good sign.  100% Asian clientele, generally a good sign.  We order Haw Gau, chow fun, baked and steamed BBQ pork Buns, Soup dumplings, Pot Stickers, "Sticky Rice Rolls", Salt and Pepper Calamari, BBQ pork.  

Service a bit slow, probably due to the fact that they aren't used to being busy on a Friday morning.  Both the BBQ pork buns were very good.  Big fresh shrimp in the Haw Gau, Soup dumplings not bursting with soup, but juicy and well seasoned.  BBQ pork was OK, but not much meat and too many of those bean things trying to make the plate look big.  Sticky Rice rolls were a bit weird.  A first for me.  Steamed dough rolled with sticky rice and spanish peanuts - Meh..... Calamari was a bit greasy and underwhelming.  Pot stickers were better than average.  $40 with tip out the door.  

Our ordering wasn't that adventurous, seeing I had my 6 and 8 year old kids with me, but they are more willing to try new stuff than most.  Overall 3 1/2 stars, but rounding up on this one because they were nice, it was cheap and they were open.  Check um out.
author: Aaron N.

description: Dim sum here is decent...my cousin is the Mayor here!  But Koi palace is still my favorite (and more pricey)
author: Joshua L.

description:
As a native San Franciscan and have dined in dozens upon dozens of Asian restaurants in this city and along the peninsula corridor, plus traveling overseas and dining at non-touristy restaurants there, estimated 95%  local Chinese restaurants serve, by their own admission, American Chinese to placate white American customers if they need that type of customer type for their profit line. Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant chooses not to compromise the choice to maintain authentic Hong Kong traditions.  Even when they include sweet and sour pork, it is prepared with higher quality than the syrupy, fatty, pineapple overly dessert sweet versions elsewhere.

Hong Kong Seafood restaurant deserves five stars, even if not consistently perfect, if compared with most other restaurants on several levels. We dined there this evening, Feb. 3 as we have previous times before. The restaurant is not fancy but cleaner with warmer lighting than 96% of the others in this city. Most Chinese restaurants are notorious for filthy bathrooms and kitchens.  This restaurant even has a vase of fresh beautiful flowers in the ladies restroom and clean.  The fish tank water is clean, whereas many other restaurant fish tanks are yellowish and murky looking.  Food here is as close to Hong Kong authentic style as can be found in this area.  I recommend trying their sauteed geoduck with bright, firm, flavorful accompaniment of vegetables.  Their House special seafood soup is generous with large tender scallops, perfectly cooked large shrimp, whole baby bok choy, pork filled wonton dumplings and other delicious ingredients in a tasty broth.  Our other dishes were deliciously memorable as well.  Whereas most other restaurants service chicken and call it minced squab with lettuce cups, Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant offers real minced squab with fresh, crisp, perfectly trimmed lettuce cups as an appetizer, but portion is generous enough as a dinner entree.  Every time we dine there, we are never disappointed.

Other Yelp customers complain about unimpressive service, but if customers fail to be courteous and gracious to the wait staff, waiters do not earn enough to suffer boorish customers.  We have always had positive experience with the service, but then we show respect and appreciation to earn pleasant service every time.
author: Lizabeth G.

description:
Now that Fook Yuen in Millbrae is closed, I've been going through dim sum withdrawal. The Kitchen and Koi Palace are okay, but I really grew to really like Fook Yuen.

So it was time for me to move on, and not compare current dim sum with my ex-dim sum ;)

Was visiting my sister in the Sunset, and I finally ate at S&T on Noriega. The dining room is small and the decor is pretty much your standard Chinese restaurant aesthetic (read: carpet, bamboo plants, pastel paint on walls).

The prices aren't the cheapest here -- with dim sum dishes ranging from $3-$5.80. Like in most dim sum restaurants (save for the big teahouses in NYC), you mark on a sheet of paper what you want. There are ladies that carry trays around with food, but on this visit, I didn't see women pushing the steaming carts of dim sim.

We ordered the basics, ha gow (shrimp dumpling), cheung fun (shrimp noodle crepe), steamed pork buns (which tasted very much like the ones you get in Hong Kong or Guangzhou), pork spareribs, two kinds of tripe (my sis's picks), soy sauce egg noodles, et al.

All in all, the food was good; nicely seasoned, served piping hot. I'd like to return to try their dinner menu.  

(N.B. If you do go for dinner, plan to wait in line for a table.)
author: May C.

description: I came here for Chinese NY dinner and it was good. The place was CRAZY crowded, felt like a zoo. The waiter we got was kinda funny and personable, unlike most Chinese restaurants. He was joking around with the tables and the food came out pretty fast, they were getting the food out fast so we could leave ASAP for the next customers. We ordered a prefixed menu with duck, appetizer plate, scallop fried rice, lobster, vegetables, lettuce wrap, soup, yes and the list goes on. I have no complaints for anything, it was all good.
author: Karen T.

description: The dim sum here is okay but the service is horrific; even for a Chinese joint.  We literally waited 40 minutes for all our dim sum dishes to arrive.  Additionally, when we asked the servers what was taking so long, they were annoyed that we asked them and claimed that it took a long time to steam which is total BS because I've been to dim sum places over 100 times by now and it has NEVER taken this long.  I will never come back here again; especially since there are so many dim sum joints in SF.
author: Weston T.

description:
This is one of my favorite Dim Sum places to go to in the Sunset. It's not expensive and the food doesn't take long! However, waiting for your table can take up to 30 minutes on those busy Sunday mornings. 

Get the Beef Noodle Roll! And the Eggplant stuffed with Shrimp! The Shanghai dumplings suck here, the bottom was so soggy. Yuck. I wana name more things, but I only the Chinese name for it!
author: Amy X.

description:
The shrimp dumplings were fantastic and flavored with sesame oil, scallion pancakes were very greasy and not that great, chow mein was ok, fried squid was pretty good, the cucumber salad was drenched in chili oil and fresh garlic... which I'm still tasting.  A long wait for an average meal, next time I might just get their take out.

No dipping, soy, or chili sauce available on the table or brought with the dumplings.  A little cheap for a place like this.

Even cheaper still:  Why are all the pencils here from San Francisco Public Schools? Not a big deal but kind of cheesy.  Our tax dollars hard at work?!  Come on people!
author: Fredricko B.

description:
OK, so I wanted to take my dad out for father's day around the Sunset District on Saturday night, but unfortunately, the orginal restaurant I wanted to take him to was completely booked so I found this place on Yelp.  Most of the reviews were about Dim Sum, which was fine.  I decided to take a chance.

As it turns out, worst choice ever made.  Initially when we walked in, everything seemed ok and noticed that there was a couple of tables that had some peanuts on their table so we asked if we can get some.  This lady, the owner, told us that you have to order it and it's $5 with a really crappy attitude.  Really?  $5 for peanuts, so my first thought was you can shove those peanuts right up your a__!!!  So, as it turns out, this lady had opened a restaurant in San Mateo that went out of business and now I know why!  She made a smart ass comment about people were ust eating up all the peanuts at that restaurant which was one of the reasons she went out of business so if we wanted peanuts, $5!  Can you say, "Beeeeyaatch!"
