How can a business owner be so loud and obnoxious????  Throughout the entire dinner, she was just rude to other patrons who had a complaint on their dishes, talking crap loudly.  Now, I grew up in a restaurant environment and just apalled on how this lady can treat her customers.  Damn shame!  She was rude, unprofessional as hell, scowling throughout the night, abrupt and didn't even have the common courtesy to say Thank you and just plopped the check on our table.

In fact, one of the dishes we ordered didn't come out and since we were almost done with the dinner, we asked the waiter to make sure that we cancel it.  The waiter told her and she responded in a loud tone, "Oh well, whatever, just give them the check!"   Wouldn't the professional response be, "Oh, I'm so sorry, but definitely, I will take it off your check."  NOTHING BUT RUDENESS!  

I would never ever, ever, ever come to this place again!  In fact, I hope they shut this place down like the San Mateo restaurant.  Although, the waiter was nice which is the only reason why I left a tip.  It was his fault!  In fact, as we got ready to leave, he apologized for his boss' behavior.  I don't see how these folks can stand working for her....  but then again, I guess they got bills too!
author: Bonnie J.

description: Maybe the food is ok, but the service is terrible!  The captain of the waiter is harassing my parents!  I will never eat there again!  Including all my extended family and my friends!
author: Irene W.

description:
I made the reservation for a party of six to have dinner with our family at this restaurant on Mother's Day.  After we sat down, we wanted the menu to order our favorite dishes.  However, the waiter informed us the regular menu was not available on Mother's Day.  Instead, we could only select from one of their dinner packages, which was based on the number of people in a party.  For six people, they offered two selections: one package for $178 & the other one for $189.

I wish the restaurant would inform me of this limited selection when I phoned in to make the reservation a couple day before Mother's Day.  That way we could have a chance to decide whether to still go & order one of the two packages or go somewhere else.  Instead they told us when we sat down and ready  to order!

We had no choices besides the two predetermined packages at $178 & $189.  The final bill came close to $300 for six people.  The worst part about this was that my family didn't even enjoy most of the dishes from the dinner package preselected by the restaurant!

I understand the purpose of business is to try & make a good profit.  However what they did was deceptive, gouging the customers.  I will never go back to this restaurant again!
author: Mary K.

description: I've been here quite a few times and I have to say, I've never had a bad experience with the food. The wait's never really too long, but the seating could be a bit more comfortable compared to other dim sum places. There's not much to say if you're a yum cha regular because everything's good, but not super good and not super bad. It's pretty decent. Especially for the price. I prefer yum cha over dinner here only because they're busier during the day, and at night they tend to stand near your tables and pay special attention to you. Some people like that, but I prefer some privacy. All in all, it's a good restaurant. Will keep coming here with the fam for sure.
author: Cindy S.

description:
This street corner restaurant has a surprisingly great selection of dim sum dishes.  The sweet soy sauce served with their rice noodle roll dishes is simply delicious.  Prices are average ~$50 for 3 people and service seemed decent.  The food here almost makes me miss living in San Francisco.

My Dim Sum Rating System:
BBQ Turnover=5
Bean Curd Skin Rolls=4
Deep Fried Taro Dumpling=4
Rice noodle roll w/ beef=5
Rice noodle roll w/ shrimp=5
Shu Mai=4
Sweet Soft Tofu=4
author: B F.

description:
For $40 two people stuffed themselves on the City's freshest, most reliable dim sum. Oh, there were leftovers. Other places seem stale and uninspired in comparison to this Sunset gem.  Best to avoid weekend crowds. Best bets: pork, Chinese broccoli, stuffed eggplant, fried lobster dumplings, green onion pancakes. One negative: bitter jazmine tea. Order poneh
There is a reason why this out of the way place appears on many "Best of SF" lists.
author: Fred  D.

description: This place is the spot to eat chinese food in the Sunset.  I am not Cantonese, and not a big fan of Cantonese food, but the quality of the food is superior here and the prices are reasonable.  I am willing to pay more for better quality food.  This place is always packed - both for dim sum and dinner.  We normally eat dinners here and I try to call in advance to make a reservation.  Tried and true favorites are the soup of the day, steamed whole fish, walnut prawns and their fu jian tofu.  We also enjoy the pork and kabocha pumpkin stew.  We never leave hungry.  They normally throw in a complimentary dessert as well (usually red bean soup which we always enjoy).
author: lucy w.

description:
All the items in the menu were first listed in Chinese and underneath listed in English.
At first I thought that was real nice,being a English person. I ordered pot stickers to
started which in english said 6 pieces for $6.75. When they came there was only 4.
I pointed this out to the waiter who brought a menu and pointed to the Chinese wording and said it says 4 pieces. I pointed the english printed under the Chinese
wording that said in English 6 pieces. He kept saying 4 pieces and I kept saying 6 pieces. So he YELLS across the dining room to the owner and turns to me and
says ok. Food was not bad, but the restaurant is dirty. The carpet is at least 25 years old and VERY DIRTY. The mens room smelled of rotten food and the cabinets were
very dirty and the room could use a serious cleaning. There is large pictures of her
all over the restaurant with different public people. Sucking butt big time.. But to 
the 4 tables around me who complained about over charging when paying the bills, she was condescending,rude and abrubt. After this experience I understand why
in this block on both sides of the street every restaurant was full of clients and this
one was nearly empty.
author: Peter F.

description: Food is decent, but the place makes me feel dirty. Plus, at least put some table cloth over the table. Had Dim Sum on a Sunday afternoon, the freakin table had Disney princess print on it. Did I sign up for "Dim Sum with the princesses" @ Disneyland? Very bad place, will return only if it's my last resort.
author: Aaron K.

description:
It's been several years since I've been here for dim sum, but I remember it being pretty good.  I especially liked the cha siu bao (bbq pork buns).

I most recently went to HK Restaurant for dinner with about 20 relatives, and the food we ordered was decent, but nothing spectacular.  The Peking Duck was good and I liked the deep fried fish fillet dish.  A little odd that we had to ask for ginger dipping sauce for our chicken, and that we didn't get extra hoisin sauce for the lettuce wrap dish.  We also ordered yi mien and ended up getting a plate full of lo mien.  

All in all, HK Restaurant is OK for dinner, but there is room for improvement.
author: Rogelio H.

description:
WOW! Had a great, delicious bday dinner for my grandma (happy 84th! :D) here last night with the fam - just awesome!! It was our first time here for dinner and after last night, I think we would definitely do it again! 

We had the:

*house soup (watercress, carrots, pork? sweet and homey)
*cold half chicken (with a ginger/garlic/green onion relish - I didn't try it but it was a hit)
*honey walnut prawns (perfectly cooked shrimp - not too mayonnaise-y, crunchy walnuts)
*spicy string beans with pork (the ground pork was so savory! and I don't even like pork!)
*ma pao tofu (deeeeelish! they do it RIGHT here!)
*gravy chow fun with beef, mushrooms and bean sprouts (i LOVE gravy noodles! even better than fried!)
*steamed fish (the soy sauce/broth in the dish was so delicate and delicious - complimented the fish so well)
(all with some good ol' white rice!)

and..

*taro/tapioca/coconut soup dessert! a GREAT ending to an awesome meal! really warmed up my soul.. terrific!

Price-wise, it'll be about $22 per person for this meal for 6 people. Not bad in terms of dinner but on the high side for a Chinese meal because right around the corner or up the block you could get a set dinner for about $60 for the same amount of people. But you wouldn't necessarily get the flavor, the service, the decor (they had the most beautiful salmon colored napkins! not the usually pepto-pink), the quality in the care that they take with their food. 

Can't wait to come back again for another amazing meal!
author: Christine C.

description:
Pretty good variety of dim sum. Enjoyed the porridges, buns, niu rou qiu, xia jiao, etc (basically the generic menu) It is a lil bit pricer than other dim sums but food was pretty good and well worth it. The place/utensils could be a bit cleaner though....found some lovely food particles waiting for me on my "clean spoon" and bowl. Easy parking though.

Bottom line: Was aiite, prolly wouldn't bragg about it but if you're around the neighborhood and got some bucks to spare, definitely worth checking the place out.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
LOVE IT! The place looks quite small, old, and usually crowded, but looks can be deceiving! The food here is DELICIOUS! One of the best places in SF for Chinese food.

I loved Shrimp Rice Noodle Rolls. For me, to determine whether a restaurant serves good quality food or not, the rice noodle rolls are the indicators. This place TOPS it! Never have I tried such soft, smooth, and tasty rice noodle rolls than this! Not even back in Hong Kong! Another indicator of a good Chinese place is... seeing Chinese bringing their non-Chinese friends here!! 

Had dinner at this place for a couple of times too. The food is outstandingly good. All authentic Chinese food!

The food is worth the price. It isn't really that expensive at all. However it cost more during dinner time. Our family loves coming here for YUM CHA every weekends. However, I suggest that you come earlier. Like any other Chinese restaurant, you will have to expect line ups for table.
author: Gordon L.

description: Good dim sum there...and they have a take out counter as well.  Their Sanpan Jook (congee/rice porridge) is really good and packed with seafood...one of the best that I have had...that is if you like that dish. Like most of the dim sum places these days, you place your order from a sheet and they bring it to you.  I miss the days when all the dim sum places hand carried or carted out the dishes for you to look  at to say yay or nay. It allowed you to be more adventurous, and is helpful if you don't know the name of the dish. There are still some places like this but not enough for my liking.
author: Stanley H.

description:
In my opinion, this is possibly the best HK seafood restaurant (especially the dimsum) in Sunset.
My method of rating dim sum is based on one dish. If it's good then I would have high remarks for the place. If not, then vice versa.
Ok, so my system may have a 99.9% chance of error, but from my experience with dim sum, if the beef tripe is good..usually the rest of the stuff are good.
HK Seafood restaurant makes good beef tripe. I repeat. HK Seafood restaurant makes GOOD beef tripe!

Moving on,

It can get busy during popular times (the case with many quality dim sum restaurants), but that's normal. 
The couple times I've been here, the parking situation is decent and you can usually avoid paying meter by parking along the residential streets.

Overall, *Thumbs up*
author: Jason N.

description:
Been there twice this month. The food is that good! This review is for dinner only cause it's a long drive for me South Bayer to have dim sum an hour away.

We had:

1) Soy sauce chicken -- tender and juicy, good flavor and just the right amount of saltiness.
2) Walnut shrimp -- had it twice and soooo good! Walnuts are fresh and crunchy, not greasy at all. Shrimps are yummy as well.
3) Steam tofu with meat sauce and reserved veggie -- good flavor, tofu could be smoother/silkier.
4) Soup of the day -- Good, homey.
5) Crab and fish soup -- Tasty, good amount of both.
6) Rice -- I ate two bowls each meal! I usually eat 1/2 bowl at home. 

Will visit again! Service was good too. Decor a little old but good food make up for it.
author: Betty A.

description: Picked up an order of Portuguese style egg custard tarts yesterday.  Been quite a long time since I've eaten these.  They were some of the best.  Tart shell is the many layered type and the filling was velvety, not rubbery like some others where they've used gelatin.  These were just eggy goodness!  Haven't been in for actual sit-down dim sum in a couple of years so can't address that.  Back then we enjoyed it for what it was.
author: Karen M.

description: Service is absolutely horrible. Waiter was super rude and condescending. Made a mocking comment towards our big party. I will never come back here again with my family and I really won't be surprised if they close their business. I wish them down the hole. I dont like them at all
author: P T.

description:
It was average at best and it's really nothing to rave about.  It's just your average dim sum house in the sunset district.   They have a "to go" place right next door for those of you who don't want to wait in line.  I came here because I had my hair cut today and this place was close by.  Plus I didn't want to go back to the North Beach district because of the Columbus Day or Indigenous People day parade and the blue angels.  Thank God this weekend is over with.  Couldn't even get into my garage because of the traffic.

Back to the food.  The decor of the place has been updated and the staff are pretty decent.  They came back to get rid of the empty plates and baskets but they never refilled our water.  I think they just wanted us out of here as soon as possible.  Can't blame them though..........they are just trying to turn tables on a busy Sunday.  Really can expect much of this place.  It aint Koi Palace and it aint as pretentious as Tong Kiang.  I don't think I can eat dim sum in the city anymore.  Too many average dim sum houses in the city.

beef roll
har gow
siu mai
tripe
sticky rice
salt and pepper chicken wings
chicken feet with black bean sauce
shanghai dumplings
shark fin dumpling soup
Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce
duck tongue
vegetarian goose(this was actually good)

Everything was just OK
author: jason g.

description:
Dinner in San Francisco may be thoroughly domesticated, but a good brunch, more often than not, is still a beast that must be hunted.  With reservations a rarity, it requires patience and planning, and those who rely on serendipity may wind up going hungry for a long time.  Of course, once you're familiar with a few good hunting grounds (and parking spots), it's not too hard to land that perfect omelet or pancake.  

But of all the brunches, none is quite as elusive, or deadly, as Dim Sum; and the dumpling hunter can all too quickly become the prey.  After all, how many people's Sundays have been laid to waste by the lines at Koi Palace?  How many would-be feasts abandoned in despairing fatigue and exchanged in famished desperation for a Starbucks muffin or (God forbid) a McGriddle?  And even those that do score a table must ask: at what cost?  For the receipt oft tallies a dim sum indeed (sorry, I just had to).

Thus, S&T Hong Kong Seafood is nothing short of a miraculous find, so much so that I really do hesitate to share it (but I'm a total review count whore, so what can I do?).  Conveniently located (for me, anyway) at 33rd & Noriega, our party of 5 showed up at 11 AM on Sunday and only had to wait 15 minutes.  Luckily one of us spoke Chinese and handled the ordering; we wound up with 16 delectable plates that we were just barely able to finish.  All in all, a perfect Dim Sum feast.  And here's the best part: the final bill was (drum roll, please) $56.  For 5 people.  Who couldn't possibly eat another bite.

Perhaps the Dim Sum wolf can be man's best friend after all.
author: Wes M.

description:
definitely a small/local place. i really dont mind that there's no carts being pushed around b/c it makes ordering food that much more efficient. however, for those that dont know the food by name, may be difficult to order. we ordered a shit ton of food ranging from the usuals to the uniques.

shrimp dumplings
pork dumplings
beef, shrimp and char siu rolled noodles
sticky rice in lotus leave
char siu steamed buns
taiwanese pork buns
green onion pancake
chicken feet
shrimp and chives dumplings
radish cakes
taro cakes
sesame seed balls
fried minced meat balls

i dont know if i was just hungry or if everything really tasted that good but it was delish. minus the rolling carts, everything is to be expected at a traditionally good dimsum place.
author: Selena H.

description:
I've been here countless times over the past year, and each time I leave feeling very satisfied. 

The dim sum is great, and I've never had a 'bad' dish. Because prices are so reasonable, I've been trying alot of different stuff each time I go, and nothing has disappointed. Just can't really remember what they're called. 

Dinnertime is good too. I really like the salt and pepper crab, the garlic fried pea sprouts, fried soy sauce noodles, chinese boiled soup, duck, chicken, fish... oh well, basically everything. 

This restuarant just sits right with me.
author: Chloe L.

description:
Definitely one of those places where you have to come early if you want to eat lunch or dinner on the weekends. 

Luckily, I've usually been here for lunch and hardly wait for a table. Our waiter often greets us in Tagalog, which I find funny and kinda sweet at the same time. My mom and her friends have been dining here for years and they don't forget about their loyal customers. 

I actually like ordering the fried rice with salted fish from here because it's not too salty. You know what I mean? Subtle enough to actually taste the other components of the dish. Dim Sum is, obviously, quite tasty here. So you can't go wrong with what you order.
author: Maria B.

description: This is a great place to go with large group (as I did for dinner).  Tables for 10 with lazy Susan's. Owners are very friendly. The food is very good as well.  Had many dishes.  The memorable ones were the pepper beaf, eggplant hot pot, and salted pork.  Red bean soup was very good as well.  All at a reasonable price.  I will definitely be back
author: p w.

description:
My family ate here on Christmas Day and had awful service. You should AVOID eating here although the food tasted decent and I liked the fish. Here's what went wrong:
 
1. We preordered a 10-person dinner. When the first people in our party arrived, they were seated in the back room. About 10 minutes later the owner lady came to the table to find out who we were because apparently we weren't supposed to be sitting there. Without any explanation, she told us this was not our table --like it was our fault that we sat there-- then moved us to a table in the main dining room.

2. When our party was complete a few minutes later, we told the waiter we were ready to eat. We had 9 people although we had preordered a 10 person dinner. 20 minutes passes and no food. My mother went to the lady owner to ask why after 20 minutes we aren't getting any food, and the owner lady had the nerve to tell her that we just arrived there when it was her that 25 minutes ago made us all get up and change tables so obviously we didn't all just arrive there. It's amazing that the lady owner can be so rude to her customers.

3. A waiter came to our table, no apology, just removed the extra setting and said he thought we were waiting for someone (just an excuse because we already told the waiter 20 minutes ago we were ready to eat).

4. At that moment another waiter brought an appetizer plate to a table next to us, and those people started eating it -- even though they were already 2 courses into their dinner. We told the waiter it looks like our appetizer is at the next table. The waiter then took that plate off their table and brought it back into the kitchen. A short time later we received our appetizer plate, and hoped it was not the one they had just brought back.

5. When the waiter brought another table next to us their dessert, the people said that they had not yet been served all their courses. The waiters huddled together, I guess to decide whether a dish was missing or not. The conclusion was that they were missing a dish and later the waiters brought them a chicken in a take out box. Then we started tracking the dishes for our dinner.
 
6. At the 2nd to the last course my mother mentioned to the waiter that we still have a dish besides the fried rice, which is typically the last course before dessert; the waiter said he would look into it. When they brought the fried rice, my mother again told the waiter that we were still missing a course (wow, is that a coincidence?!)  The lady owner then came to our table to see what food we were having and told us that the kitchen claims they cooked the dish. She also said nobody admitted to eating our dish. The lady owner thought maybe we already ate the dish. We told her to look at our table of food that we didn't get that dish. We wanted the dish but lady owner didn't want to give it to us, and said she will refund some money for that dish. We had been there almost 2 hours already, and there was an empty table next to us so they didn't need our table. You would think lady owner would want to serve us the dish and make money on the dish we preordered but she refused.
 
7. For our trouble, they brought us a complimentary dessert of some mango sticky ball, which was nice until they tried to add it to the bill later.

8. When the bill came they tried to charge us tax and tip on the dish that we never received. They only deducted the amount of the missing dish after tax and tip was included in the original total. While speaking with lady owner that we shouldn't be charged tax and tip on a dish that we never received, she said that she would fix it but she decided to add the "complimentary" dessert to the bill so that we can pay tax on it, stating that we need to pay tax to Obama. The amount that she added to the bill for the "complimentary" dessert was almost as much as as the cost of the missing dish. Isn't that rude to try to add things to the bill to make us pay tax on something we never ordered? Owner lady rudely states she's spending a lot of time redoing the bill to make me happy.
 
9. After asking a waiter's opinion of whether she should charge tax and tip on the complimentary dessert and missing dish (don't ask me why she is asking a waiter), owner lady redoes the bill back to the original then manually deducted the missing dish and the tip on the missing dish. She was still not deducting the tax on the dish we never received. I got tired of trying to get her to deduct the tax. 

10.We decided we're never coming back to this restaurant!
author: B L.

description:
I feel that many of the negative reviews of this restaurant are unfair.  I am not Asian but I love Chinese cuisine and know it well, and this restaurant does a great job.  Yes, the woman in charge is quirky and moves you right along, especially when they are busy.  Yes, there are few Caucasian customers but the service seems the same--prompt and efficient--for every customer.  Yes, their prices are higher than Asian restaurant average in the Outer Sunset but they give you outstanding quality and very large portions.

I notice that many of the complaints concern their Dim Sum.  This is not a Dim Sum place and so why go there for that when there are restaurants dedicated to Dim Sum all over SF.  At this restaurant, I always order from the Chef's Special list (BTW they should put their menu through an English language spell-checker).  The Frog's Legs dishes are outstanding, particularly the one in hot ginger.  Also their vegetable dishes are excellent; try the green beans one.  For an appetizer, the Mu Shu pork is tops--huge portion.  I like spicy food and always ask them for some hot sauce.  Instead of plunking a plastic bottle of Thai hot sauce on the table like many Chinese restaurants do, S&T Hong Kong Seafood gives you a bowl of their own freshly prepared hot sauce.   And it's really good.  It's touches like that that makes this place special.
author: Murray S.

description:
I know I shouldn't write a review about this place because now all you will go there and I won't be able to find a seat. When it comes to Dim Sum, we all know we want Koi Palace and House of Banquets, but is it worth the wait. I hate waiting especially after a long night of drinking and an empty stomach, where would you go for food? 

The only solution would be a nice bowl of noodles or Dim Sum. I learned about this place through a friend and now I'm a fan. I've been here three times last month and it's fantastic. Fresh Dim Sum at low prices. Sure, the location is a bit far but parking is easy to find and if you have a small party, the wait is not bad. The service is decent just like all the other Dim Sum places, but you find that anywhere.

Always order the shrimp and pork dumplings, the tripe isn't bad either. If you like chicken feet, knock yourself out, I rather bite something else than that. Eww...how can you eat that? That is gross!
author: Stanley K.

description: Awesome Dim Sum, every dish was perfect, tea was filled quickly. It was a little odd that the owner put pictures of herself up everywhere but whatever, it's her restaurant. I would definitely make another trip here.
author: Don W.

description:
After waiting for TWO HOURS at the doctor's office with my grandmother (see previous review), we were starved, so we walked over here for lunch. I'd been here several times before and it was typical dim sum. The manager, or whoever the hell that snooty man in the suit is, seated us quickly. Fast forward to an hour later, when he walks by and ignores us when we are clearly trying to get his attention. RUDE. I don't care how good the food is; if customer service sucks, nothing can make up for it. Don't get me started on how they screwed up our orders. AND THEY WEREN'T EVEN BUSY. It was a Wednesday morning. Imagine how it is on the weekends!! We ordered some kind of Malaysian noodles for my uncle and specifically told them we wanted it to-go, but they served it to us. Understand that my aunt actually told them in Cantonese so it's not like it was me giving them instructions in my broken Canto. 

The manager (owner?) was so pretentious, you'd think they were serving gold-covered shrimp dumplings here. Not even close. It was average--not all that and a bag of chips. Anyway, his pictures are hung everywhere in the restaurant, so he must be someone important. Guess he forgot about the little people on his way up.
author: Audrey T.

description:
I just ate there for dinner today, and they were packed!  However, we were lucky to have reservations.  I will not rant on about what they do/ do not have to offer, as the list will go on and on.

In the restaurant, there are two sides.  The side on the left, where you enter. . . and the side to the right, where there is another room.  Normally, I am seated to the right, where two waiters serve you.  (If you've read my previous review, this refers to the two waiters.)  However, I was seated on the left side, where there were another two waiters, and a waitress.  Service, I must say, was great.  They were much friendlier, and did not constantly pester us to order the "larger" plates.  Also, they changed our plates three times.  I am unsure to why service immensely improved - because of the different waiters/waitresses, or because that we were a party of thirteen?

Now, onto the food.  Their dim sum is a favorite, secondary to the expensive and packed Koi Palace.  Their siao long baos almost match those of Koi Palace, and this place's shrimps puffs are definitely the best.  Just don't order pot stickers here, they aren't that tasty, and lack that delicious crisp.

Dinner time!  Some waiters, as mentioned above, tend to insist that you order a larger portion.  Bigger = more expensive, like the customer doesn't know that.  When you reject his suggestion, his friendliness lessens.  Still, their food is yummy.  Again, I love shrimp puffs - I order them every time.  Their crab and lobster are delicious, and almost all dishes are satisfactory.  This is one of the family's first choices for family dinners.
author: Christina C.

description:
THE SERVICE HERE IS HORRIBLE!

We waited over 2 hrs for a table, and when we finally got our table, it took a long time for our food to get served. After finally getting our food, and finished eat, we asked for our bill. On the bill, they wrote down and CIRCLED the time we spent at the table. They noted that we spent over an hour at the table and required us to pay a 20% tip because we spent a long time eating.  Of the many dim sum restaurants that I have been to, I have NEVER been charged a mandatory 20% tip fee for "taking too long to eat", and half the time was spent waiting for our food. Not only that, but they swiped my credit card and did not ask me for my signature. I had to ask them for a copy of my receipt and that was when I realized they automatically charged 20% tip WITHOUT my signature. I told them there was no sign or anything written down that requires a mandatory 20% tip, and they told me never to come back. 

I DO NOT RECOMMEND S&T HONG KONG RESTAURANT TO ANYONE!
author: Angela W.

description: This review is only for the lunch time dim sum.  I've never tried their sit down menu for dinner.  It's one of the few dim sum restaurants in the Sunset. Decent food at decent prices.  The wait can be quite long on weekends, so get there early.  It's my go-to dim sum restaurant when I don't feel like venturing out too far.  Lazy weekend stop.
author: Stacey L.

description:
My review is actually for 3 1/2 stars and it is mainly for the food itself (dim sum). 

So, this is the new favorite place for the in-laws. After hearing about the delicious shrimp stuffed tofu, we had to give it a try. We went at about 11:30, which was prime time for dim sum diners. Even though the hostess told us 15 minutes, we waited for at least 40 minutes.  Anyhow, not much room to wait inside, so be prepared to wait on the sidewalk. I wouldn't mind, but you can't hear the numbers being called outside, so you have to send a scout inside to brave the crowd. 

When we finally got seated, I have to say it was worth it. You order via menu (no carts here). Which, has its pros and cons. Pros: the food comes out HOT! And, you fill up on what you like, instead of eating squid and jelly fish cause that is the only cart that comes by. Cons: not all the dim sum items are in english. Some are only written in Chinese. So, you might miss some tasty items if you can't read Chinese. 

Overall, the dim sum was great! Service, eh. A return trip definitely.
author: Mashi M.

description: Love love LOVE their dim sum. I also enjoy having the option of take out instead of eating in the restaurant. The quality of the food is just as wonderful compared to eating in. I get amazing service as well! Best place in the sunset!
author: Jenn G.

description:
Upping to four stars based on the quality of food at dinner. Recommended: salt and pepper crab, black pepper beef on a sizzling platter, Peking spareribs, vermicelli and satay beef in a clay pot, and the roast duck.  The latter comes out with crisp skin on a bed of  soybeans.  The West Lake beef soup is quite tasty as well.

They fixed their dim sum menu and now everything is listed in English and Chinese.

This place is relatively expensive at dinner. Non-seafood main dishes are in the $10-15 range.  S&T Hong Kong is probably the best Cantonese restaurant in the Sunset/Parkside area.  It was packed at dinner on a recent Tuesday night. That's quite a feat in this day and age.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: Good option for Dim Sum in the City. Prices were a little higher than what I'm used to seeing since I normally Dim Sum in the East Bay, BUT, the dumplings were quite big, packed with Shrimpy, Porky goodness. My party of 4 went nuts and I believe we ended up ordering around 16 dishes, which is WAY too much, but it's just so easy when you're checking off all the things you want to try on their order form. Service was pretty good for dim sum, and the staff was friendly though pretty harried throughout the restaurant. Even with all that we ordered, the total bill came out to about $15/pp, which is still quite reasonable.
author: Phuoc K.

description:
Solid three star restaurant.  

Service: It was brisk, but not rude or whatever everyone else below has said.  They forgot one dessert, but it was fine as we were all totally stuffed by then. 
 
Price: Went with a group of 6, and we ate and ate and ate and ate for $25 a head... 

Food: Great XO noodles and noodle rolls, the shitake shu mai didnt seem too different from regular shu mai, the prok buns were right there, the potstickers were huge, not to be confused with the fried pork dumplings which were deep fried balls of dough with porky stuff inside... I had a lobster roll too which was good, but deep fried.  I prefer steamed to fried as it is less filling and I can try more stuff!! The desserts were good- there's a deep fried bread/dough strip that I guess usually comes with sweet milk, but was served plain- could have definitely used some powdered sugar at least.  

Process: I liked the fact that we ordered from a list, as my friend put it, you're not waiting to see if your favorite thing comes out- takes the apprehension out of it, you just wait and eat and dig the goodness.  

Location: I live in Oakland so this was kindof a schlep, but I will vow to take my dog to the beach more and pick up some to go stuff from here, fun Sunday outing!  Parking wasn't awful at 11am, one circling of the block and I got a spot dead across the street.

Try it, and if you are scared of the service- do take out.
author: Catherine R.

description: I've been here twice for dim sum. The place has been crowded both times which speaks for itself. We had to wait a bit, but it was nothing absurd. The dim sum are all pretty good and they are fairly attentive. It's definitely worth a try, but do get there early!
author: Sharon G.

description:
This is the best Dim Sum in San Francisco (and Koi Palace, because everyone compares Dim Sum to THAT place).

First, this is good Dim Sum, not 'In and Out.' Expect to wait at least 30 minutes during peak times. Dim Sum is meant to be done over a period of longer than a hour with friends, delicacies and tea.

The ingredients taste fresher (and probably are due to volume) than other Chinese restaurants. You can taste the subtle differences when the flavors explode in your mouth. It is really hard to quantify good dim sum, but this is it. The tea doesn't come from a bag, the dim sum is cooked fresh and the service is quick. The hot sauce isn't from a jar on your table that has been sitting around for 6 months.

My favorites here are:
Pan Fried Chive Dumpling: A shrimp and chive cake that has been grilled on both sides like a panini to add in flavor.

Shrimp Dumpling: Yeah it just tastes better here. No lies. I mean this is the real litmus test of a restaurant. For those of you not in the dim sum know: This is what it sounds like, shrimp with a bit of oil, starch and salt steamed in dumpling form.

Noodle Rolls: Probably the big stand out. Most dim sum places offer shrimp noodle rolls and beef noodle rolls but this place has a bunch. And it is of note because they really pack a bunch. I recommend the BBQ noodle roll and the chive noodle roll (vegan). Not in the dim sum know? These are rice noodle rolled around a filler and then drenched in soy sauce. The medley is very tasty with the right mix of acidity and sweetness.

I'd add those on with your favorites and enjoy.

Also their signature is a soy sauce chicken (12$ half/23$ whole). Another thing I cannot explain, but if you go here for dinner be sure to order it. Again it is what it sounds like, soy sauce and chicken! But they must have some secret process to bring out the flavors.
author: Joe Z.

description: For a white male just looking for some good dim sum, this place is great. They had everything I wanted, and even the stuff I didn't (cold chicken feet? ew!). Other than the crummy service and "White devil" stares I was receiving from the other customers and wait staff, this place is fine by me. To me, if you have good food, then I don't care if you have dog-shit service.
author: Alex G.

description:
I've dined here with my family's  friends; who introduced us to this restaurant.   They dined here  frequently since  we've gotten excellent customer service from the staff.
 
I've had dinner and lunch here. Their dim sum was very good. 

Since they ordered the meal, i can't recall  what  they ordered. But it's been very delicious meals and a great experience here that when my family (we're from the south bay) are in the area; we make an effort to come to this restaurant. 

But one unique  entree is their (ju gang yuk)  pig's neck.  It looks like char siu, but very  delicious.  This is an entree that we often order from this restaurant.  

It does get  busy on Sunday evenings.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
They have a side door for dim sum to-go. I was walking by around lunch after buying a roast duck and pig ears down the street.

I decided to duck in to take a quick look at their goodies. While the lady behind the counter wasn't the nicest and the food was in a glass case, when I brought it back home and heated the items on the stove, they were actually pretty damn good.

I got a set of turnip cakes, chive & shrimp dumplings, and fried sticky rice savory dumplings. They were all pretty good compared to other to-go joints that I've tried along the 28/29 MUNI routes.

I won't go out of my way for them, but I'll visit when I'm in the area.

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description: The staff services were awful, rude and horrible on Chinese New Year.  I don't want to talk back especially on CNY.  I know think they care on if I return back for dim sum or not since they have enough neighborhood business but I felt I need to speak up this time. I noticed the portion is getting smaller and okay.  Well, anyway they need to provide better services and talk less.   The chop sticks, plates and cups need to be little cleaner.
author: Love To Eat C.

description:
Edit 01/23/08

I'm excited to see all these new and positive reviews for this place! They're such nice people. I hope they get more and more business!!
_______________________________________

Came here for dinner. Service was excellent! Food was just absolutely yummy!! Every dish I had was made perfectly. Good cantonese restaurant. I want to try their dim sum...

The waiters are hilarious!
author: J T.

description:
I went to S & T Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant for Dim Sum with my family this weekend.   There was not really a very long wait, but it was a very hot day and the place does not have air conditioning.  When we got our table, the first thing I noticed was there were still food stains at the edge fo the table.  The bus person must not have wipe the table before turning it over to the next guests, which was us.  The dishes and bowls also had food stains on them.  I have to rinse them off with hot tea.

The food there was just OK and the service was so so.  There were flies everywhere, but that is what you expect when you go to a Chinese dim sum restaurant.  There was only one bathroom and inside was so dirty, paper on the floor, and the floor was wet.  There were also little critters living inside the walls which I don't even want to say it, you know what I mean.

I wish the owner would take better care of the place and not be cheap. It used to be a very good place in the Sunset District, but I will not be coming back to this place anymore.
author: Angela T.

description:
Uh...when did this place get so bad?  I've been here multiple times for dim sum and I remember it being pretty decent.  However, I went on Friday with my parents and the food was horrible.  We were seated right away because of our small party but the service went downhill after that.  Our food took forever to come and the waiters were very hard to flag down.  I even heard other parties complain about the service.

As for the food, we ordered har gow, shiu mai, ja leung, chicken feet, siu long bao, shrimp roll, shark fin soup, and salt and pepper calamari.  The most disappointing dishes were the ja leung and siu long bao.  The ja leung was literally just the donut wrapped in noodle.  No dried shrimp or green onion...ugh. And the siu long bao was very dry.  There were no juices inside the dumpling at all!  The best thing was the calamari.  Is it a little weird that their calamari is better than their dim sum?!?

I am never coming back here for dim sum!  There are definitely better places to go in the city!
author: Helen V.

description:
There aren't many sit-down dim sum restaurants in the Sunset...so I pretty much come here with my family by default. It also helps that I only live two blocks away. 

The quality of the food here doesn't compare to Koi Palace...but it's above average and it gets the job done. There are also a few items you can get that's under $2...like this deep-fried tofu we always get. 

There are a number of items that are written only in Chinese...so it could be hard to mark off what you want if you can't read it. Good thing my dad is always there with me. 

Definitely try to avoid the typical lunch hours on weekends/holidays...you'll be waiting for quite a while if you don't come early. Parking also sucks...so just park at my house and walk over! 

The service here kind of sucks. Unless you know them, they can be pretty rude. Some of the ladies who bring out your food are nice though...so be nice and show some gratitude. I think I saw one waiter work with his Ipod on...I really hope I was seeing things.
author: Allan M.

description:
Usually, the service at Asian joints are mostly insanely fast coz they wanna get you in and out quick to get more turn around. This place is NOT the case.

-Slow service (some people need chili dammit! now!)

-Food was alright. Not great. Came out very slowly unlike most dim sum joints.

-Half the menu was in mandarin, not translated. So we had to point like monkies to the dish from the next table.

1 star to the excellent egg tart. flaky pastry...YUM
1 star to a fairly cheap meal
1 star to the shrimp-paste-stuffed-in-a mushroom-that-we-don't-know what-its-called-coz-it-wasn't-in-english. 

I'd give this place 2 and a half stars. Minus half for the slow service....they have a lot of wait staff to go around so no excuse compared to smaller restaurants.
author: Marcia O.

description:
Yum dim sum. You can't really go wrong with dim sum. We didn't really know how popular this place was until we got there. There was a line, but as with almost all Chinese restaurants, they go by quickly. We waited probably only 15 min or so, but we also did luck out with a party of 2 who didn't show (and what do you know, we're also a party of 2). 

Food was good, dim sum, again, is yummy. The only thing that bothered me was the ridiculous amount of flies next to the window where our table was. The flies didn't bother by flying around, but they were just there, on the window, staring at us (or not). The prices are a little steeper (a small is 2.20, medium is 2.80, large is 3.80) but that's because I'm accustomed to the cheap so-cal dim sum of 1.80 for all sizes. 

Can't rate the normal food (I'm guessing seafood is the specialty?) but check out the dim sum for lunch.
author: Yosie G.

description:
We just tried this restaurant for the first time and I think it is the  BEST dimsum place in SF.

It is SLIGHTLY higher priced than other places but totally worth--everything from the dishes (which includes some unusual Malaysian dimsum/dishes) to the tea (even the hot mustard and chili sauces) was outstanding. AND friendly waiters/waitresses a bonus!

Let me describe to you the sublime taro cake and malaysian steamed cake:

taro cake: many julienned slivers of REAL taro pressed together in perfect thickness (about 1/2 inch) and fried to crisp brownness on both sides; tender and tasty inside.  Like a thick delicious taro hash brown!

malaysian steamed cake:  yellow, soft, pillowy, not too sweet, slightly lemony filling.  Rolled up like a jellyroll.  3 in a bamboo steamer.  Beautiful to look at and delicous to eat.

Friday afternoon at 1:30 pm was perfect--no waiting, waiters/waitresses were all chill and friendly and attentive, parking was super duper easy, etc.
author: Karen C.

description: Food-wise, I am impressed! Decor and restaurant itself need work, but we're here for the food. I've gone here many times with my parents when I used to live in the Sunset. I'd pick HKSR over Koi Palace any day. Food here is less expensive and good size portions. My dad took me out today and we had the following: egg custard (Portugese style....much better than regular ones), eggplant stuffed w/shrimp, pan fried taro, preserved egg/pork porridge, shrimp dumpling, and bitter melon wrapped in rice noodle. All was good and I'm sure the rest of the usual dim sum items are good, at least they looked good when they passed by our table.
author: Marcus Y.

description: Authentic Cantonese food and decent service. Decor remodel is about a decade overdue; its falling apart. That said, the wait staff was friendly and attentive. Food came out piecemeal, but it was delicious.  And, they take reservations.
author: Ike K.

description:
I would only recommend this place if only to remind you why you appreciate the good dim sum places. Why? Let's begin my sordid tale of mediocre Chinese dim sum. 

The gf and I had some errands to run, and it just so happened that we were in the neighborhood. Instead of the typical run to Mongkok Dim Sum, we came here, figuring that we could sit down and actually eat something, instead of on the go for a change. 

We ordered, har gow, some Chinese garlic spare ribs, shanghai dumplings, donut noodle roll, shrimp noodle roll, egg rolls, deep fried shrimp balls, and chicken feet. Everything was ok, not special. But when I tried the spare ribs, I started to tank. I felt queasy in the stomach, and need to take in some air. The plates weren't really cleaned, and the cups that I drank my tea in had a greasy film to it. Even though it's listed as a 98 in cleaniness, I think the REAL score is more like a 78. There's no way this place gets a 98 in scoring, unless they're kicking back some cash to the inspector. The tables are dirty, dishes are greasy, and the people who bring you food to your table, NEVER wipe or clean the utensils which they use to cut up your food. 

Service was way below average. There wasn't many people, but apparently it took them over 20 minutes for us to get our check, and they forgot to bring us our deep fried shrimp balls. I wish I had avoided this place, but I can't help but feel that we got screwed over in service, and in the quality of food. The prices are definitely not good, as in I can get better service and quality of food elsewhere in the city, and be content. 

In the end, this place isn't worth it, and I really don't see how people still rave about this place, when it's obvious it's not.
author: Clinton L.

description:
Jackpot!

One of the best dim sum places in San Francisco that I've found so far!

We cautiously tried this place after seeing the reviews on Yelp - and we were pleased!  (What luck - my Japanese friend is forever hooked on dim sum now!)

Conveniently located on the 71 line, and plus there's lots to walk around in the area if you're waiting for a table on a busy Sunday morning (always a good sign though!)

Thanks Yelp!
author: Haywood H.

description:
This review is for dinner only. Pricey, but the food was alright. We had the banquet/family style menu for dinner for 2 big tables. There were different prices to choose from. The $298 per table one was yummy -- had lobster, scallops, abalone, shark fin soup, cold platter, fresh fish, etc. The soy sauce chicken is REALLY good!!!

It was a week night, so the restaurant wasn't too busy and the service was very very good. The waiters and the manager lady were very welcoming and service was quick. They cut and served the birthday cake we brought, and boxed up our leftovers.

Birthday person gets a gift certificate ($15) to spend at the restaurant again, so we'll have to come back.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Dim sum this past weekend. had to wait forever for a table. good thing i had a slight snacky before going. 

we ordered way too much food. i really liked their sticky rice since it had weird sausage and egg yolk in it. everything came out steaming hot, and I burnt my tongue quite a lot since i don't have patience (we know that already)
author: Yummy P.

description:
I haven't been here in a few months but I came here for dinner the other night and had one of the worst dining experiences ever.

When I first went in with my family, the hostess led us to a table cramped into a corner. My mom shifted the table slightly in order to make a little more room to get into the seats but the waiter rudely burst out at us that the table was immovable and to not mess with it. First strike.

When we finally settled down, I noticed that the worn-out paper wrapped around the chopsticks had sauce stains on it and were taped up. I find this to be very unsanitary to be re-using these wrappings. They might as well not use the wrappings at all for it is a hazard rather than a decor. Second strike.

The worst of all, however, was the service. The waiter was extremely rude. This was the same waiter who shouted at us for moving the table. He sounded extremely annoyed by our patronage. He repeated all our orders in a loud, abrasive tone of voice like we didn't know what we just ordered. (In Chinese: "Four ice waters please." "FOUR ICE WATERS."; "I'd like a steamed egg with scallops..." "STEAMED EGG WITH SCALLOPS.")

The food wasn't very horrible, but not fantastic either. (We ordered the daily soup that day which was papaya with chicken feet soup...it tasted DISGUSTING...it had the aroma of a public toilet and a very strange taste, like that of old milk. Third strike.) Even if the food HAD tasted good, the overwhelmingly impolite waiter would've ruined the whole dining experience anyway. Try not to come here if you can help it.
author: Cheri S.

description: This morning was the second time my husband and I came to this place to have food.  Honestly, the food is about average. The service was horrible the first time and I even wrote a complaint on the receipt.  Since we live in this area and we wanted to give this place a try one more time, however, we are still disappointed.  The worst part is that the waitress even complained in cantonese in front of us and other customers that I only paid them 15% tip. For sure not coming back again.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Came here last night for dinner. My dad was trying to impress me by saying even Leland Yee has eaten here. I don't care how famous the person is, as long as the food is good. 

We ordered ma po tofu, a pepper onion and red pepper beef dish, plain chicken, yow choy with mushrooms, and the egg white scallop fried rice. 

The chicken I cannot comment on because I didn't have any. I had the rest of the dishes and they were ok. The tofu dish wasn't that spicy because it's suppose to be. The fried rice had chiese broccoli steam cut up. It wasn't fully cooked, but the the rice dish was ok. Everything was good, but when I go home I was thirsty. Someone mention they put MSG in it. 

I really had to drink a bottle of water a home to cure my thirst. I don't know if I would come back just to eat the tofu dish, but if someone said go, I'd go. Service was kind of slow. The waiter that took our order went outside for a smoke and then came back in to take our order. Not sure if you're suppose to do that and the fact he didn't wash his hands makes it kind of gross.

Service was ok. You have to flag down a waiter to get them to refill your tea pot.
author: Jen C.

description: Ok Dim Sum filled with MSG.  Not such great service.  Do not order the Lobster Lomein, you will get a claw challenged one(YOU WILL GET NO CLAWS!).  They will rip you off.  If you have any allergy to MSG do not eat here since I was extremely sick from MSG from eating here.  I got a headache and very thirsty and drank 3 large glasses of water as soon as I got home.  This place sucks!
author: Jim J.

description: Ordered sweet and sour pork to-go for dinner last night, got home and my family and I each took one bite of it and we all immediately spit it out in disgust...the sweet and sour pork was battered in all pork FAT no meat at all, yuck!!!  What a great way to ruin dinner S&T Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant, I applaud you so that's why you get one star, yay!!!  I agree with some of the reviews that they pick and choose how they treat their customers. If you're a regular, they'll treat you like poo-poo literally because the food they serve you is sh*t!  And if you don't speak Chinese they'll take advantage of it and serve you low quality disgusting Chinese food because they think you won't know the difference between good quality Chinese food (exactly what they did to me last night).  This place is super dirty too, don't let the nice lighting, pictures with the mayor, and decorations fool you. Eat here with caution or at your own risk!!!
author: Mary T.

description:
The food here is quite alright, for Chinese food (which I'm not a big fan of). But the service can kiss my ass!! Actually, the service can kiss all of our asses at the table. First off, we had freakin reservations and still had to wait. Good, you're busy. But our waiter was soo effin rude, arrogant and basically TELLING US what to order and not to order. NO, it was NOT a SUGGESTION. He was of course trying to get us to order the most expensive things there were, and saying shit like, "what?? that's not good.. of course order this". Blah blah blah. Every word that came out of his mouth was garbage and it took us forever to just flag him down each time we wanted something. Finally, of course the hostess/manager (possibly even owner by the way she addressed us) apologized a million and probably gave us something on the house. 

Oh yeah, did I mention the food isn't bad?
author: Elaine H.

description: Overall, the food is good.  The service is acceptable but not the best.  Ladies, do NOT wear skirt to this place.  I am the only one in the family who wore a skirt, and I got bitten by bugs in four different places.  I am not sure if they are bed bugs or fleas.  I am not impressed by this place at all.  If you like good food, go to R&G Lounge in San Francisco China town.
author: Summer R.

description:
Wow!  I see a lot of reviews saying the service sucks...  I could see how a lot of people would say that.  The waiters are actually kinda rude but I think they are doing it for fun.  Somehow, when I ate here the night before Lunar New Year, seems like my parents knew these rude servers and that they were just "joking" around.  At first, I was like, damn, they are freaking messed up but after a while, I just kinda laughed it off cause my mom was messing with them too.  

Anyhow, the service is attentive but they can be rude but to me I took it as dry humor.  But the food is pretty top notch for a Chinese restaurant and the decor is pretty cool too.  Prices are a little higher than your typical neighborhood spot but the decor IS nicer and the food IS better so I guess you have to pay for it.  But don't worry, it doesn't hit Koi prices so we are still ALL GOOD.....
author: Mark W.

description:
I am SO surprised that everyone rates this place poorly for service.  We received GREAT service here!  I seriously mean this wholeheartedly.  Granted, it wasn't slamming busy but, at the same time, it wasn't slow either.

They actually took the time to answer any random questions we had about the differences between certain items (can't remember the specifics) and the lady with the dishes cruising around the room pointed to the items on our list when we asked what they were (she didn't speak much English).  Our waiter asked us if we needed any sauces (we got oyster sauce for the broccoli) and we asked him repeatedly for others (hot oil, sweet/sour, soy).  He brought them promptly without attitude.  It could have been the bright sunny day that made the service "sunny" as well!

All of our dishes were super tasty...especially the duck chin!  It still had the tongue attached!  How cute!

This (along with Mayflower) are now my two fave dim sum spots.

In regards to service...maybe you get out of it what you put in (in terms of smiles!)?
author: Sandy K.

description:
Since I live in sunset, I used to go to the restaurant in the neighbourhood. Though I have tried many other restaurants, I still find the best food in here.

I love the crab noodles, pork porridge, steamed BBQ pork bun, deep-fried taro, shrimp rice roll, and everytime I would finish my dim-sum lunch with a nice to-fu-fa (dessert).

I am a lucky one who can always get a table within 10 mins, even on weekends.  Why? coz I go there after 1:30pm usually!  It worths to starve until the lunch hour has passed because you could have better service and more attention after peak hours.
author: Woodspy T.

description:
GET THE ROASTED QUAIL.

Everything else was standard issue.  Slightly above par.  This place has been around for decades - shows for something to weather the Noreiga restaurant row storms.  They remodeled a few years ago, so the place looks clean and somewhat modern.  

Service stinks.  They were busy as heck Sunday night, but to shoo us away minutes after paying the bill was pretty rude.  Shes that butch short haired Asian aunt you hated to visit when you were younger.  Yeah, that one.
author: Isaac L.

description: My current favorite take-out dim sum place in SF.
author: Jeff X.

description: Come here for dim sum once in awhile.  Just a typical Sunset Chinese restaurant...nothing special.  The place is a bit old and not all that clean looking.  Their dim sum items is mediocre but prices are not too bad.  However, I do like their shark-fin dumpling soup...they have humongous shark-fin pieces in em!!  All other items...just typical-average...
author: Patrick C.

description:
Dayam, this is damn good chinese food!

Came in on a Monday night and we were asked if we had reservations. Since we didn't, it was a 30 minutes wait for a table for 3.  The place was busy for a Monday. Apparently, my boss is a regular there so they went a pulled out a table from the back because the manager felt my boss was waiting too long. Unfortunately, we were given a old rickety table right next to the kitchen exit and the fish tanks of nasty looking fishes.

But from sitting next to the kitchen exit, I saw that everything that came out of there looked amazing! Not like the usual chinese restaurants where they just drop it from the wok to the plate, but everything was nicely arranged. 

I don't like to drink a lot of chinese soup, but this is great! Then my favorite dish of all - salt and pepper spareribs, cooked to perfection! They're known for their soy sauce chicken, delicious as well. The assorted seafood pot was bubblingly delcious.

Being an ABC, I don't hold myself to being an expert in which restaurants tastes good in terms of chinese food, but S & T is tops in the sunset district! Even with the crappy seating, they still get the full ratings!
author: Cavan W.

description: Very decent dim sum. It gets crowded on the weekends. The pork buns are great, as is anything with shrimp.
author: Mosey S.

description:
I've walked by Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant countless times as I traveled by foot from my home to the grocery store. HK Seafood always appeared as some form of epicurian challenge I had to conquer for some reason. Since being transferred to The City, my goal has always been to try every restaurant in town. HK has been in my sights since my first passing. 

HK, when open, always was either filled inside or had a small customer base outside waiting to get in. To me, I always thought to myself this was a good thing! 

In attempt to plan ahead and make my first time at HK something special I planned for Thanksgiving dinner at HK. I didn't tell my wife and she was somewhat reserved in us going out to eat in our neighborhood for Thanksgiving dinner. I would of been as apprehensive as her knowing the shortage of "western" style food in our part of town. 

So, after putting on our Sunday best and slowly strolling up Noriega towards HK the anticipation was building inside me. We arrived and immediately noticed the small crowd waiting outside. No problem I thought. I stepped up to the hostess and proudly exclaimed, "two for dinner"! She looked at me as if I just spoke in some foreign tongue. I guess I did to her as she continued to just stare at me in total wonder. She scribbled something on the table sheet and gave me a scrap of paper with something else scribbled on it. After roughly 15 minutes of enjoying the warm Thanksgiving sun and the company of the other well-dressed diners we were ushered to our table. 

Our next challenge was in attempt to put ourselves at ease. There we were. The only Anglo-Saxon looking folks seated squarley smack dab in the middle of a sea of Asian families. After we slowly realized that not every eye in the room was staring a hole through our heads we relaxed and perused the menu. I knew what I wanted and didn't want the tasty morsels, as described on the menu, to dissuade my decision from my self-determined culinary experience. 

Either it was planned or our good fortune was shining upon us as the waiter arrived at our table side speaking perfect English. I told him what I wanted ... Dungeness Crab prepared anyway the chef would care to experiment with. I told the waiter I wanted the crab on a bed of spicy/garlicky noodles as well as a platter of vegetables. The waiter stood there with this look of indecision and question. The waiter spoke, "so ... you want the crab anyway the chef thinks he should prepare it? Is that what you said?" I looked directly into his eyes and gave him the affirmative. The waiter's face then lit up as if I just offered him the Mayor of San Francisco job. He stated the chef will be delighted to prepare the crab my way and he suggested the vegetables. Of course I had no idea what the hell he just named but when he offered a pair of frosty Tsing-Tao brewskis to start the evening off I knew we were going to be ok. 

Our meal arrived and as it did you would of thought I ordered deep-fried kitten. Again we experienced the un-easy feeling of every eye in the room starring a hole through, what is now the room's visual target ... our food. Which can only stated, was truly excellent. 

The crab, which by this point, morphed into two Dungeness crabs was excellent. We had a Salt and Pepper crab and a deep-fried crab. Both fantastic. I had no idea what the heck the vegetable was but it was excellent. The noodles were great and just what I was hoping for. The combination of the noodles, crab and veggies was way more than my wife and I can eat. The leftovers were truly appreciated later that night.

At this point my wife was starting to become somewhat at ease. I was as well. We were now receiving thumbs up from our fellow diners on our choice. The little kids were all over but it gave the establishment a nuance that was necessary for the feeling of Thanksgiving. 

Bottom line: Hong Kong Seafood Restaurant was excellent. The food was tasty, the service was perfectly fine and the decor was simple and clean. We were made to feel at home and thoroughly enjoyed our time and dinner. 

We will be back!!
author: Wayne B.

description:
Very decent choice in the Outer Sunset.  Kat was visiting from Boston and put a request in for good chinese (somewhat lacking at back there) Crowds of cantonese families wait patiently in the cramped space by the door, while the fog  roils around one's ankles.  We waited ~15 minutes to seat a party of seven plus baby.  When we tried to order from the chinese menu, the waiter demurred, saying we wouldn't like it.  But when we insisted brought out an appetizer plate of bbq pork, roasted duck, jellyfish and duck's tongue.
All of which was delicious altho the squeamish in our party refused to face the gauntlet (to our waiter's satisfaction).
Sizzlin rice soup was clear broth and good chunks of seafood.
Crispy hong kong style egg noodles came with a tasty sauce
claypot eggplant & beef shortribs
dau miu and garlic (peashoots)
whole deep fried fish
spicy pork chow fun

all very good dishes, used some MSG (as reported by sensitive friends).
Not sure on prices since our fabulous friend Thanya picked up dinner.
Good neighborhood option.
author: SatisFahYing A.

description:
Went for dim sum on a Saturday. Took a bunch of newbies who have never been -- unfortunately, no carts, but rather ordering food from a tick-off menu. 

A number of things aren't translated into English, which always leads me to believe there's something good not being shown to the Westerners. Which includes the best item we ate - squid with spicy salt. Really incredibly light squid that melted in the mouth - and I am a connoisseur of this dish. We arrived at it by marking something random on the sheet next to Chinese, which they were out of, and so we got this dish.

Second best dish - an amazing plate of "Tender Chinese Greens" with garlic, that I simply asked for, since it wasn't on the menu.

And the best "actual" dim sum was the shrimp har gau - dumplings - really delicious and light with a flavor that didn't require soy sauce to accompany. 

Most of the dumplings were excellent. 

Service was taciturn at best. 

Beautiful looking giant clams and crabs in the tanks - might go back for those!
author: Seth N.

description: I used to love this place. We would go there all the time, in fact 2xs a week to be exact. For some reason, it doesn't taste as good as it did before so we stopped going. Maybe it was just an off day. But, if my memory serves me well, their food is decent.
author: Jordan W.

description: I love their dim sum! So fresh, tasty and well prepared, unlike some other places that serve frozen microwavable items. They have an extensive dinner menu as well, which comes with colorful and mouth watering pictures, I personally enjoy looking at the pictures more than reading the descriptions. The dishes are very authentic (not crazy), and high quality. The only downer is the long wait.
author: Kai Z.

description:
I can't say I've had dim sum enough to be an expert but of all the places I've been I'd say this was definitely the best.  And the strange thing is, it's cheaper than other spots that weren't as tasty.  They have all the standards, all done well, and if you can read or speak chinese you have an extra section of menu opened up to you.  My advice is go with someone who can speak chinese, but some of those "hidden" items are a little more adventurous if you're just used to basic dim sum or chinese food.  The non dim sum menu is good as well.  It's a little pricier than the average chinese restaurant in the sunset by a few dollars per item, but it is better than some of those cheaper spots.  So it is worth it.

Aside from the restaurant they also have a dim sum to go right next door, but it closes at 4, but that's a definite bonus.
author: Raffi Y.

description:
This restaurant is full of new experiences:

We came in with a party of 20 and half way through the meal, the staff ask us if we could kindly fit into one table so that they could give one of the tables to other patrons who were waiting.  

In another visit, the waiter said a few of our chairs were blocking the aisle so he asked if we could move the table for him 4 feet towards the wall...because you know, it's not like this is the restaurant staff's job.

Have you ever ate vegetables that contained steel pot scrubbers?  Me either, until this place gave served up a plate of Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce and strands of steel pot scrubber.  I guess this is their special ingredient.

This restaurant is on the same block as ABC and I never knew that it was possible to have a health inspection score lower than ABC who at least gets 70s.  Yet somehow this place managed to earn a score of 34 and  42. I think the restaurateur confused the health inspection with golf.  I wonder if the pot scrubber vegetables have anything to do with this.
author: James Y.

description:
I think this place offers the best dim sum in the sunset. The steamed dumplings are always very fresh with quality ingredients, and piping hot when they reach the table. The dumpling skins are very thin (which always indicates good and fresh dim sum to me!) My favorites include the typical HK favorites- shrimp dumping, siu mai, beef and shrimp noodle rolls, and the black bean spare ribs. 

We also ordered the crispy seafood noodle dish. They were very generous with the seafood. The vegetable was fresh, and the sauce was nice and not overbearing with thickening agents or MSG.

expect to wait 30 minutes+, and spend $15+ pp for weekend brunch. service isn't too great, but the dim sum makes up for it.
author: Kelsie L.

description: This is an "order off the menu" dim sum place. Food is good and for six items the price was $25 with tax and tea. The lobster dumplings though tasted more like shrimp than lobster but still good.
author: John S.

description: In my opinion, this is one of the best Cantonese hk style restaurant in the area. We are usually very picky regarding food. A good friend of us recommended it, it was late at night and we brought our guest here to taste some real Cantonese foods. Dinner is absolutely fantastic! not sure about their dim sum etc. But the white chicken is definitely A+, near the famous chingyen style. Beef is great! tofu is A+. Service is great. environment is ice and cleaner than 90 percent of the Chinese restaurants we been to. Price is reasonable. overall its a fine restaurant!
author: Sunny N.

description:
I came here with a group of friends on Saturday around 11 for dim sum.  This place was busy, but luckily they had a larger table available for us and we didn't have to wait too long.

The food was oily and I mean everything.  We had the usual dim sum items, har gow, siu mai, chicken feet, rice noodles, turnip cake, egg tart, etc..  All of it had way too much sauce.  We also ordered a dry noodle and it tasted all the same.

The service was good, prompt, and not too rude for chinese waiters. The price was on the higher side for the mediocre food.

I may come back to try dinner sometime, but most likely not.
author: Kirk K.

description: I have been going here for many years.  IMHO, it is the best dim dum in SF.  It is always fresh, hot and not greasy.  The staff is friendly and helpful.  Today,  I took a friend visiting from Hawaii, very familiar with dim sum.  We ordered a number of dishes, but the waiter suggested we reduce our order!  Can believe that...spend less?  He was right.  Even with this, we left with a doggie bag.  Always happy with the yummy selections.
author: Anita K.

description: my top two go to dimsum...crowded lines on weekends crowded during the week..good solid food... if you time your visit you can watch the food shift from one genre of dim sum to another...better than mayflower! better than tong kiang!
author: Ricote F.

description: OH HELLS NO!!  I am never coming back here again! I was treated like a 3rd class citizen begging for food, the servers were ignorant and so rude.  Everyone in the restaurant were screaming and I felt like I was back in China; this visit to this restaurant gave me flashbacks to the culture shock I had had before. Terrible!  After 25 mins of trying to get my to go order, the food was mediocre, but the headache I got was an amazing 10 on the pain scale. goddamn!
author: Hana ..

description: Gotta have dim sum fast and you live south of GGP?  Head to Hong Kong Seafood take out (next door to the restaurant).  It's tiny - 3 people are a crowd, but the women who work behind the counter are efficient.  Steamers are right there, plus there's more in the counter.  Don't see what you want?  No problem, they'll go back to the restaurant kitchen.  This is basic dim sum, tasty, but not high end like Ton Kiang.  Parking is non-existent, so plan ahead.
author: Janice P.

description: My favorite local spot for dim sum on the weekends. The trick is to order from the To-Go counter to the right of restaurant. Parking is a bitch, so make your significant other drive while you jump out.
author: Tommy O.

description:
You ever think about a place to say...
"Man, if only I owned this place!"
Great name... great locale... Clean decor... Bright... Comfy...
I'd fire EVERYBODY!

Don't even think of coming in early like 5pm to get a head start on dinner, because everyone is scurrying around like... like... a Chinese fire drill. We were greeted and seated quickly, but one of our party must have accidentally hit the cloaking device, because nobody saw us for about 15 minutes. So after the next 4 parties got seated, dealt their menus, and had their tea served, they sent us the dreaded... NEW GUY. He's the one that whenever you ordered a dish... you had to show him where in the damn menu it was. You can just feel the shroud of apprehension looming over the table. The final nail in the coffin? He brings us an order of clams with black bean sauce, I ordered CRAB with black bean sauce. He even shows me where it's listed on the damn menu! So WHAT... I said CRAB!   Whatever...  
We also had to listen to American Idol type show music on their sound system. You know what a stickler I am for ethnic authenticity... oh well.

I must say that the food was pretty decent. The beef in black pepper sauce was tender, and the Honey Walnut Prawns were excellent. Lot's of prawns too. I bet the crab would've been great! Items are a bit pricey. Cheapest dish was $9.50 all veggies, no meat. Figure the average per dish is $11-$12. Portions are just alright. Lots of Asian patrons, but it's an Asian neighborhood in the Sunset. Parking can get rough, but not as bad as like Clement St.

Still, if I come back... it won't be my idea.
author: Rick V.

description: I believe ownership has changed, because the food is so much better! I've been here for dim sum twice in the past month because the dim sum was tasty and hot when it came out. Service is decent as well. This is now my go-to option when I don't feel like driving to Koi Palace.
author: Tina T.

description:
It's sad to say that there are not enough Chinese dim sum restaurants in the Sunset. Unbelievable that there are so few out here with the Chinese population being so freaking high.

And if you don't have enough restaurants to push each other to out do the other, then you will be left with this. A very mediocre place with shitty ass service and some very annoying employees.

Let's start with the food. That's almost their saving grace but not really. The food here lacks consistency. Take, for example, their XO noodles. One day, it would be beautifully cooked. Nice and dry and not too oily with great spicy flavoring deep inside the noodle along with the wonderful flavor of dark soy. The next day, lightly colored noodles with hardly any spice in them and very oily. Stir frying something like this is not that hard. And the noodles are pre-packaged stuff so they take the guess out of that. Unbelievable!

Now, for the employees. We've been coming here when we were looking for a house in the Sunset. Kinda stuck with us and been coming ever since. Dad likes this place more than the other place on Ulloa and 20 something. Not sure why... But the staff here sucks balls then and still sucks balls now. The only difference was the female that was the manager a couple of years ago is now the owner, I think. Explains her picture on the wall. She's a nice lady that is hard working and takes care of a lot of things even when eating with friends or family. Very diligent. Can't say the same for the rest of the crew. Some of the waiters are cool. Some are just fucking stupid and lazy. And the servers. One of them seems to be a fucking race to see who can push out the most food. She's also the same one that wants to see how much sauce she can wear in one shift. Too fast and too sloppy. And there's a couple others that look like they're all hot shit. You work as a dim sum pusher, bitch! This ain't no Miss Hong Kong! And the two bitches that run the front of house and do the cashier work. The one with the glasses needs a mirror to see that she is an ugly ass bitch. And the other one with the sour look on her face needs to stop talking to me in english when I speak perfect Cantonese to her. Acts like she passed her TOEFL exam or some shit.

That being said, I still come here. But not by myself or with friends. With my family. If I had a choice of this place and Koi Palace, I would go to Koi. Not that that's the lesser of two evils. That depends on who's cooking that day...
author: Anthony L.

description: Just went there earlier today because we were in the city and my mom loves their soy sauce chicken. Unfortunately we went there right at 5pm and they dont have the chicken ready until after 6pm boo. We didn't have a reservation, but it seemed like everyone else there did, so good thing we DID get there before dinner time. The place is pretty clean and the service is good. We ordered broccolli with some kind of mushroom, sweet & sour pork, beef & onions, honey walnuts & prawns, and some sort of dried fish with baby lotus root. It all came out delicious and we were well satisfied. The prices are more than reasonable and the portions are good, especially since we had 6 hungry people, we were able to still bring home left overs. OH! and we got sliced oranges at the end.
author: Elisa T.

description: the food was only mediocre and not enough to justify the terrible service we recieved.  they gave us the wrong food, then charged us for it despite us telling them about the overcharge when we got our bill.  they have an obvious disintrest to a low paying table since it was just my husband and i and we both wanted a simple meal of rice and noodles.  we dont expect stellar service, but at least to be treated justly.  and there must be some incentive to come back right?  but the food just was not special.
author: Lynette F.

description: I've been here plenty of times with my family whenever we have those family gathering dinners. This place is pretty good I must say. It is pretty clean which means you wouldn't need to fear about what goes on in the kitchen with your food. This place is probably one of my favorite Chinese restaurant because it is not too pricey.
author: Edgar G.
